The increasing use of these agents is based on their ease of use and rapid killing activity against micro-organisms; however, they should not serve as a replacement for proper hand washing unless soap and water are unavailable.

Gukomeza gukoresha ubu buryo bishingiye ku kuba bworoshye gukoresha no kuba bwica vuba udukoko twanduza; gusa, ubu buryo ntibukwiye gusimbura uburyo bwagenwe bwo gukaraba intoki keretse mu gihe isabune n'amazi bidahari.
Frequent use of alcohol-based hand sanitizers can cause dry skin unless emollients and/or skin moisturizers are added to the formula.
Gukoresha kenshi imiti isukura intoki irimo arukoro bishobora gutuma uruhu rwuma keretse muri iyo miti hongewemo iyo koroshya uruhu cyangwa ituma rudakanyarara.
The drying effect of alcohol can be reduced or eliminated by adding glycerin and/or other emollients to the formula.
Uko kuma kw'uruhu bitewe na arukoro bishobora kugabanyuka cyangwa bikavanwaho na giliseline cyangwa undi muti woroshya uruhu.
In clinical trials, alcohol-based hand sanitizers containing emollients caused substantially less skin irritation and dryness than soaps or antimicrobial detergents.
Mu bushakashatsi bwo kwa muganga, imiti isukura intoki irimo arukoro ariko ikanabamo umuti woroshya uruhu ituma uruhu rudakomera cyane kurusha amasabune cyangwa imiti yica mikorobe.
Allergic contact dermatitis, contact urticaria syndrome or hypersensitivity to alcohol or additives present in alcohol hand rubs rarely occur.
Gufurutwa kw'uruhu, kuzana uduheri cyangwa kwivumbagatanya k'umubiri bitewe n'arukoro iri mu muti usukura intoki bibaho gake.
The lower tendency to induce irritant contact dermatitis became an attraction as compared to soap and water hand washing.
Kuba hari ibyago bike byo kwangiza uruhu bituma ubu buryo bukoreshwa cyane ugereranije no gukaraba intoki ukoresheje isabune n'amazi.
Despite their effectiveness, non-water agents do not cleanse the hands of organic material, but simply disinfect them.
N'ubwo bikora neza, ibisukura intoki bitarimo amazi ntibisukura intoki ngo bimareho umwanda wose, ahubwo bikuraho udukoko twanduza gusa.
It is for this reason that hand sanitizers are not as effective as soap and water at preventing the spread of many pathogens, since the pathogens still remain on the hands.
Niyo mpamvu rero umuti wo gusukura intoki udakora neza nk'isabune n'amazi mu kurinda ikwirakwizwa rya virusi nyinshi, kubera ko virusi ikomeza kuba ku ntoki.
Alcohol-free hand sanitizer efficacy is heavily dependent on the ingredients and formulation, and historically has significantly under-performed alcohol and alcohol rubs.
Imikorere myiza y'imiti isukura intoki itarimo arukoro ishingiye cyane cyane ku biyigize, kandi kera yahoze idakora neza nk'arukoro n'ibindi bisiga bikomoka kuri arukoro.

More recently, formulations that use benzalkonium chloride have been shown to have persistent and cumulative antimicrobial activity after application, unlike alcohol, which has been shown to decrease in efficacy after repeated use, probably due to progressive adverse skin reactions.

Vuba aha, imiti ikoresha chloride ya benzalkonium yagaragaje ko ifite ubushobozi buhoraho bwo guhangana na mikorobe nyuma yo kuyikoresha, bitandukanye n'arukoro, byagaragaye ko umusaruro itanga ugenda ugabanuka nyuma yo kuyikoresha inshuro nyinshi, bitewe wenda n'ingaruka igenda igira ku ruhu.
Many people in low-income communities cannot afford soap and use ash or soil instead.
Abantu benshi mu bafite imibereho iciriritse ntibashobora kubona isabune bityo bagakoresha ivu cyangwa itaka.
Ash or soil may be more effective than water alone, but may be less effective than soap.
Gukoresha ivu cyangwa itaka ni ubundi buryo bwiza buruta gukoresha amazi gusa, ariko nanone si bwiza cyane nko gukoresha isabune.
One concern is that if the soil or ash is contaminated with microorganisms it may increase the spread of disease rather than decrease it.
Impungenge imwe ihari ni uko ivu cyangwa itaka bigizwe n'utunyabuzima duto cyane dushobora kwanduza bityo bikaba byakongera ikwirakwizwa ry'icyorezo kurusha uko byarigabanya.
Like soap, ash is also a disinfecting agent because in contact with water, it forms an alkaline solution.
Kimwe n'isabune, ivu naryo ryica udukoko twanduza kubera ko iyo rihuye n'amazi rikora aside.
WHO recommended ash or sand as alternative to soap when soap is not available.
Mu gihe isabune itabonetse, Ishami ry'Umuryango w'Abibumbye ryita ku Buzima risaba ko hakoreshwa ivu cyangwa umusenyi.
Correct handwashing technique recommended by the US Centers for Disease Control for prevention of transmission of disease includes the following steps:
Uburyo bukwiye bwo gukaraba intoki bwasabwe n'Ikigo gishinzwe kugenzura no gukumira indwara muri Leta Zunze Ubumwe z'Amerika mu rwego rwo gukumira ikwirakwizwa ry'iki cyorezo ni ubu bukurikira:
Wet hands with warm or cold running water.
Tosa intoki ukoresheje amazi akonje cyangwa ashyushe kandi atemba.
Running water is recommended because standing basins may be contaminated, while the temperature of the water does not seem to make a difference.
Amazi atemba ni yo agomba gukoreshwa kuko amazi ari mu ibase ashobora kubamo ubwandu, kandi igipimo cy'ubushyuhe bw'amazi ntacyo gihindura cyane.
Lather hands by rubbing them with a generous amount of soap, including the backs of hands, between fingers, and under nails.
Karaba intoki zizeho ifuro, uzikuba cyane ukoresheje isabune nyinshi, ukarabe inyuma y'ikiganza, hagati y'intoki no munsi y'inzara.
Soap lifts germs from the skin, and studies show that people tend to wash their hands more thoroughly when soap is used rather than water alone.
Isabune ikura ku ruhu udukoko dutera indwara, kandi ubushakashatsi bwagaragaje ko abantu bakaraba neza intoki iyo bakoresheje isabune kurusha uko bakaraba bakoresheje amazi gusa.
Scrub for at least 20 seconds.
Kuba intoki nibura mu gihe cy'amasegonda 20.
Scrubbing creates friction, which helps remove germs from skin, and scrubbing for longer periods removes more germs.
Gutsirita intoki cyane bituma habaho kwikubanaho, bigafasha mu gukura ku ruhu udukoko twanduza indwara, kandi kuzikuba cyane bikuraho utwo dukoko twinshi.
Rinse well under running water.
Tosa neza intoki ukoresheje amazi atemba.
Rinsing in a basin can recontaminate hands.
Gutohereza intoki mu ibase bishobora kongera kwanduza intoki.
Dry with a clean towel or allow to air dry.
Umutsa intoki ukoresheje igitambaro gisukuye cyangwa uzumutse ukoresheje umwuka.
Wet and moist hands are more easily recontaminated.The most commonly missed areas are the thumb, the wrist, the areas between the fingers, and under fingernails.

Intoki zitose cyangwa zitumutse neza zishobora kongera kwandura ku buryo bworoshye. Ahantu hakunze kwibagirana ni ku gikumwe, mu bujana, mu mwanya uri hagati y'intoki, ndetse no munsi y'inzara zo ku ntoki.
Artificial nails and chipped nail polish may harbor microorganisms.
Inzara z'inkorano cyangwa inzara ziteye amabara zishobora kuba indiri ya za mikorobe.
Moisturizing lotion is often recommended to keep the hands from drying out; dry skin can lead to skin damage which can increase the risk for the transmission of infection.
Amavuta y'amazi yo koroshya uruhu ni yo abantu basabwa gukoresha kugira ngo intoki zidakanyarara; uruhu rwumye cyane rushobora kwangirika kandi ibyo bikongera ibyago byo gukwirakwira kw'icyorezo.

Various low-cost options can be made to facilitate hand washing where tap-water and/or soap is not available e.g. pouring water from a hanging jerrycan or gourd with suitable holes and/or using ash if needed in developing countries.In situations with limited water supply (such as schools or rural areas in developing countries), there are water-conserving solutions, such as "tippy-taps" and other low-cost options.

Hari ubundi buryo buciriritse bushobora gukoreshwa mu rwego rwo koroshya igikorwa cyo gukaraba intoki mu gihe uburyo bwo gukoresha robine cyangwa isabune budahari, urugero nko gusuka amazi hakoreshejwe ijerikani imanitse ku giti (kandagirukarabe) cyangwa se igicuma kirimo imyenge yabugenewe cyangwa hagakoreshwa ivu igihe bibaye ngombwa mu bihugu biri mu nzira y'amajyambere. Mu gihe hari ibibazo by'amazi (nko ku bigo by'amashuri cyangwa mu bice by'icyaro mu bihugu biri mu nzira y'amajyambere), hari uburyo bwo gufata amazi nka kandagirukarabe n'ubundi buryo buhendutse.
A tippy-tap is a simple technology using a jug suspended by a rope, and a foot-operated lever to pour a small amount of water over the hands and a bar of soap.
Kandagirukarebe ni ikoranabuhanga ryoroshye rikoresha ijagi imanitse ku mugozi, isuka amazi hakoreshejwe ikirenge, ugakaraba amazi make make mu ntoki n'isabune.
Effective drying of the hands is an essential part of the hand hygiene process, but there is some debate over the most effective form of drying in public washrooms.
Kumutsa intoki mu buryo bukwiye ni igice cy'ingenzi cyane mu kugirira isuku intoki, ariko ubu haracyari impaka ku buryo bwiza cyane bwakoreshwa mu kumutsa intoki mu bwiherero rusange.
A growing volume of research suggests paper towels are much more hygienic than the electric hand dryers found in many washrooms.
Ubushakashatsi bwinshi bugaragaza ko impapuro zikoreshwa mu kwihanagura ziba zifite isuku cyane kurusha ibyuma byumutsa intoki bikoresha amashanyarazi biri mu bwiherero bwinshi.

In 2008, a study was conducted by the University of Westminster, London, and sponsored by the paper-towel industry the European Tissue Symposium, to compare the levels of hygiene offered by paper towels, warm-air hand dryers and the more modern jet-air hand dryers.

Mu 2008, Kaminuza ya Westminster i Londere itewe inkunga n'uruganda rukora uduhanaguzo rwitwa "The European Tissue Symposium", yakoze ubushakashatsi bugamije kugereranya ikigero cy'isuku itangwa n'uduhanaguzo, utwumutsantoki n'akuma kagezweho kumutsa intoki.
After washing and drying hands with the warm-air dryer, the total number of bacteria was found to increase on average on the finger pads by 194% and on the palms by 254%.

Nyuma yo gukaraba no kumutsa intoki ukoresheje icyuma cyumutsa intoki gikoresheje umwuka ushyushye, byagaragaye ko ingano rusange y'udukoko dutera indwara yiyongera ku mpuzandengo ya 194% ahashyirwa intoki ndetse no hagati mu kiganza ku mpuzandengo 254%.
Drying with the jet-air dryer resulted in an increase on average of the total number of bacteria on the finger pads by 42% and on the palms by 15%.
Kumutsa intoki ukoresheje icyuma gihuha umwuka byatumye ingano rusange y'udukoko dutera indwara yiyongera ku mpuzandengo ya 42% ahashyirwa intoki ndetse no hagati mu kiganza ku mpuzandengo 15%.

After washing and drying hands with a paper towel, the total number of bacteria was reduced on average on the finger pads by up to 76% and on the palms by up to 77%.The scientists also carried out tests to establish whether there was the potential for cross contamination of other washroom users and the washroom environment as a result of each type of drying method.

Nyuma yo gukaraba intoki no kuzumutsa hakoreshejwe impapuro zabugenewe, umubare wose w'agakoko wagabanyijweho ku mpuzandengo ya 76% ku duhanagurantoki no kuri 77% ku biganza. Abahanga kandi bakoze ubushakashatsi kugira ngo barebe niba habaho kwanduzanya hagati y'abantu bakoresha ubwogero ndetse n'ahabukikije bitewe na buri bwoko bw'uburyo bwo kumutsa.

The jet-air dryer, which blows air out of the unit at claimed speeds of 180 m/s (650 km/h; 400 mph), was capable of blowing micro-organisms from the hands and the unit and potentially contaminating other washroom users and the washroom environment up to 2 metres away.

Agakoresho kumutsa, ka kandi gasohora umwuka ku gipimo cy'umuvuduko wa 180m/s (650km/h; 400mph), kashoboraga gukura ku ntoki n'ibindi bice udukoko twanduza ndetse n'ubushobozi bwo kwanduza abandi bakoresha ubwogero ndetse no kwigizayo utwo dukoko mu ntera igera kuri metero 2.
Use of a warm-air hand dryer spread micro-organisms up to 0.25 metres from the dryer.
Gukoresha icyuma cyumutsa intoki gikoresheje umwuka ushyushye bitumura mikorobe kugeza muri metero 0.25 uvuye aho icyuma kiri.
Paper towels showed no significant spread of micro-organisms.In 2005, in a study conducted by TÜV Produkt und Umwelt, different hand drying methods were evaluated.
Uduhanaguzo dukoze mu mpapuro twagaragaje ko tudakwirakwiza cyane mikorobe.Mu 2005, mu bushakashatsi bwakozwe TÜV Produkt und Umwelt, hasuzumwe uburyo bunyuranye bwo kumutsa intoki.
The following changes in the bacterial count after drying the hands were observed:
Impinduka zikurikira zagaragaye mu mubare w'udukoko twanduza indwara nyuma yo kumutsa intoki:
Many different hand dryer manufacturers exist, and hand driers have been compared against drying with paper towels.
Hariho abakora ibikoresho byo kumutsa intoki benshi, kandi ibikoresho byumatsa intoki byagereranyijwe n'impapuro z'isuku zumutsa intoki.
Hand washing using hand sanitizing wipes is an alternative during traveling in the absence of soap and water.
Gukaraba intoki ukoresheje umuti wabugenewe usukura intoki ni ubundi buryo bwakoreshwa mu gihe umuntu ari mu rugendo adafite amazi n'isabune.
Alcohol-based hand sanitizer should contain at least 60% alcohol.
Arukoro yagenewe gusukura intoki igomba kuba igizwe nibura na 60% by'arukoro.
Medical hand-washing became mandatory long after Hungarian physician Ignaz Semmelweis discovered its effectiveness (in 1846) in preventing disease in a hospital environment.
Gukaraba intoki kwa muganga byabaye itegeko nyuma y'uko umuganga wo muri Hongiriya witwa Ignaz Semmelweis avumburiye akamaro kabyo (muri 1846) mu kwirinda indwara mu bitaro.
There are electronic devices that provide feedback to remind hospital staff to wash their hands when they forget.
Hari ibikoresho by'ikoronabuhanga byibutsa abakozi bo kwa muganga gukaraba intoki iyo babyibagiwe.
One study has found decreased infection rates with their use.
Hari ubushakashatsi bwagaragaje ko kubikoresha byagabanyije igipimo cy'ubwandu.
Medical hand-washing is for a minimum of 15 seconds, using generous amounts of soap and water or gel to lather and rub each part of the hands.
Gukaraba intoki mu rwego rw'ubuvuzi bimara nibura amasegonda 15, hakoreshejwe isabune nyinshi n'amazi cyangwa umuti wabugenewe utuma haboneka ifuru maze ugakubira hamwe ibiganza byombi.
Hands should be rubbed together with digits interlocking.
Intoki zigomba gukubirwa hamwe zinyuranamo ku buryo bwegeranye cyane.
If there is debris under fingernails, a bristle brush may be used to remove it.
Niba hari umwanda munsi y'inzara, uburoso bwabigenewe bushobora kuwukuramo.
Since germs may remain in the water on the hands, it is important to rinse well and wipe dry with a clean towel.
Kuko udukoko twanduza indwara tuguma mu mazi ari ku ntoki, ni ngombwa gutosa neza no kumutsa cyane intoki ukoresheje igitambaro gisukuye.
After drying, the paper towel should be used to turn off the water (and open any exit door if necessary).
Nyuma yo kumutsa intoki, agahanaguzo gakozwe mu mpapuro kagomba gukoreshwa mu gufunga amazi (ndetse no gufungura umuryango usohoka niba ari ngombwa).
This avoids re-contaminating the hands from those surfaces.
Ibi birinda intoki kongera kwanduzwa n'aho zakoze.
The purpose of hand-washing in the health-care setting is to remove pathogenic microorganisms ("germs") and avoid transmitting them.
Impamvu yo gukaraba intoki ahatangirwa serivisi z'ubuvuzi ni ukugira ngo hakurweho mikorobe zishobora gutera indwara no kwirinda kuzikwirakwiza.

The New England Journal of Medicine reports that a lack of hand-washing remains at unacceptable levels in most medical environments, with large numbers of doctors and nurses routinely forgetting to wash their hands before touching patients, thus transmitting microorganisms.

Ikinyamakuru cyandika ku buzima kitwa "The New England Journal of Medicine" gitangaza ko gukaraba intoki mu mavuriro bikiri ingorabahizi, aho usanga umubare munini w'abaganga n'abaforomo bakunze kwibagirwa gukaraba intoki mbere yo gukora ku barwayi; ibi bikaba bituma udukoko twanduza indwara dukwirakwira.

One study showed that proper hand-washing and other simple procedures can decrease the rate of catheter-related bloodstream infections by 66 percent.The World Health Organization has published a sheet demonstrating standard hand-washing and hand-rubbing in health-care sectors.

Hari ubushakashatsi bwagaragaje ko gukaraba intoki n'ubundi buryo bworoshye bishobora kugabanya ikigero cy'indwara zandurira mu nzira y'amaraso ku kigero cya 66%. Ishami ry'Umuryango w'Abibumbye ryita ku buzima ryashyize ahagaragara inyandiko igaragaza uburyo bwizewe bwo gukaraba intoki no gukoresha imiti yifashishwa mu gusukura intoki mu nzego z'ubuzima.
The draft guidance of hand hygiene by the organization can also be found at its website for public comment.
Umushinga w'amabwiriza y'isuku y'intoki atangwa n'ikigo ashobora kuboneka ku rubuga rwacyo kugira ngo abantu bayatangeho ibitekerezo.
A relevant review was conducted by Whitby et al.
Ivugurura ry'ingenzi ryakozwe na Whitby n'abandi.
Commercial devices can measure and validate hand hygiene, if demonstration of regulatory compliance is required.
Ibikoresho by'ubucuruzi bishobora gupima no kwemeza isuku y'intoki, niba hasabwe kugaragaza ibisabwa n'amabwiriza.
The World Health Organization has "Five Moments" for washing hands:
Ishami ry'Umuryango w'Abibumbye ryita ku Buzima rigena "Ibihe bitanu" byo gukaraba intoki:
after exposure to blood/body fluids
nyuma yo kugira aho uhurira n'amaraso/amatembabuzi
before an aseptic task, and
mbere y'igikorwa cyo kuvura, na
after patient care.The addition of antiseptic chemicals to soap ("medicated" or "antimicrobial" soaps) confers killing action to a hand-washing agent.
nyuma yo kwita ku murwayi.Kongera imiti yica indwara ku isabune (amasabune "akoreshwa nk'imiti" cyangwa "ayica mikorobe") bituma gukaraba intoki bidufasha kwica udukoko twanduza.

Such killing action may be desired prior to performing surgery or in settings in which antibiotic-resistant organisms are highly prevalent.To 'scrub' one's hands for a surgical operation, it is necessary to have a tap that can be turned on and off without touching it with the hands, some chlorhexidine or iodine wash, sterile towels for drying the hands after washing, and a sterile brush for scrubbing and another sterile instrument for cleaning under the fingernails.

Ubwo buryo bwo kwica mikorobe, bushobora gukenerwa mbere yo kubaga cyangwa ahantu higanje cyane ibinyabuzima bihangana n'imiti irwanya indwara.Kugira ngo ukube intoki neza mbere yo kubaga, ni ngombwa kugira robine ishobora gufungwa no gufungurwa udakoresheje intoki, umuti w'isuku wa chlorhexidine cyangwa iodine, igitambaro gifite isuku cyo kumutsa intoki nyuma yo kuzikaraba, ndetse n'uburoso bufite isuku bwo gukuba intoki ndetse n'ikindi gikoresho gifite isuku cyo gusukura inzara zo ku ntoki.
All jewelry should be removed.
Ugomba kwiyambura imitako yose.
This procedure requires washing the hands and forearms up to the elbow, usually 2–6 minutes.
Ubu buryo busaba gukaraba intoki n'amaboko kugeza ku nkokora, akenshi hagati y'iminota 2 kugeza kuri 6.
Long scrub-times (10 minutes) are not necessary.
Gukuba intoki igihe kirekire(iminota 10) si ngombwa.
When rinsing, water on the forearms must be prevented from running back to the hands.
Mu gihe uri gutosa amaboko, irinde ko amazi ari ku maboko yongera kumanukira ku ntoki.
After hand-washing is completed, the hands are dried with a sterile cloth and a surgical gown is donned.
Nyuma yo kurangiza gukaraba intoki, zihanaguze igitambaro gisukuye maze wambare umwambaro wo mu cyumba cy'imbagwa.
To reduce the spread of germs, it is better to wash the hands or use a hand antiseptic before and after tending to a sick person.
Mu rwego rwo kugabanya udukoko twanduza, ni byiza gukaraba intoki cyangwa gukoresha umuti woza intoki mbere na nyuma yo kwita ku murwayi.

For control of staphylococcal infections in hospitals, it has been found that the greatest benefit from hand-cleansing came from the first 20% of washing, and that very little additional benefit was gained when hand cleansing frequency was increased beyond 35%.

Mu bugenzuzi bwakorewe ibitaro bivura indwara ziterwa n'udukoko twitwa "sitafilokoke", byagaragaye ko inyungu nyinshi iva mu gusukura intoki ituruka muri 20% ya mbere yo gukaraba, naho inyungu nkeya yiyongeraho ikaboneka iyo inshuro zo gusukura intoki zongerewe kugera hejuru ya 35%.

Washing with plain soap results in more than triple the rate of bacterial infectious disease transmitted to food as compared to washing with antibacterial soap.Comparing hand-rubbing with alcohol-based solution with hand washing with antibacterial soap for a median time of 30 seconds each showed that the alcohol hand-rubbing reduced bacterial contamination 26% more than the antibacterial soap.

Gukaraba ukoresheje isabune isanzwe bitanga umusaruro urenze inshuro eshatu mu kigero cy'indwara ziterwa n'udukoko two mu biribwa ugerereranyije no gukaraba ukoresheje isabune yagenewe kwica udukoko twandura. Iyo ugerereranyije gukoresha umuti basiga mu ntoki n'isabune yagenewe kwica udukoko twandura mu gihe cy'amasegonda 30, byose byagaragaje ko gukoresha imiti yifashishwa mu gusukura intoki bigabanya kwandura udukoko ku kigero cya 26% ugerereranyije n'isabune yagenewe kwica udukoko twandura.

But soap and water is more effective than alcohol-based hand rubs for reducing H1N1 influenza A virus and Clostridium difficile spores from hands.Interventions to improve hand hygiene in healthcare settings can involve education for staff on hand washing, increasing the availability of alcohol-based hand rub, and written and verbal reminders to staff.

Ariko gukaraba ukoresheje isabune n'amazi ni byo byiza kurusha gukoresha imiti yifashishwa mu gusukura intoki mu rwego rwo kugabanya virusi y'ibicurane bya A/H1N1 n'utundi dukoko dufite ubukana dusigara mu ntoki. Ibikorwa byo kunoza isuku y'intoki mu mavuriro bishobora kubamo no kwigisha abakozi gukaraba intoki, kongera imiti yifashishwa mu gusukura intoki no kubyibutsa abakozi mu buryo bwanditse ndetse no mu magambo.
There is a need for more research into which of these interventions are most effective in different healthcare settings.
Hakenewe gukorwa ubushakashatsi bwinshi bugaragaza uburyo ubu bufasha ari ingirakamaro cyane mu kwita ku buzima ahantu henshi hatandukanye.
In developing countries, hand washing with soap is recognized as a cost-effective, essential tool for achieving good health, and even good nutrition.
Mu bihugu bikiri mu nzira y'amajyambere, gukaraba intoki n'isabune bifatwa nk'uburyo bw'ingenzi kandi buhendutse bwo kugera ku buzima bwiza, ndetse n'imirire myiza.
However, a lack of reliable water supply, soap or hand washing facilities in people's homes, at schools and at the workplace make it a challenge to achieve universal hand washing behaviors.

Nyamara, kutabona amazi ku buryo buhoraho, isabune cyangwa ibikoresho bifasha mu gukaraba intoki mu ngo z'abantu, ku mashuri n'aho abantu bakorera ni imbogamizi ikomeye ituma kugira imyitwarire yo gukaraba intoki ku bantu bose bitagerwaho.
For example, in most of rural Africa hand washing taps close to every private or public toilet are scarce, even though cheap options exist to build hand washing stations.

Dutanze urugero, mu bice byinshi by'icyaro muri Afurika, robine zo gukarabiraho intoki ziri hafi y'ubwiherero rusange cyangwa bw'abantu ku giti cyabo ziracyari nkeya, nubwo hari ubundi buryo buhendutse bwo kubaka ahantu ho gukarabira intoki.
However, low hand washing rates rather can also be the result of engrained habits rather than due to a lack of soap or water.
Ariko, umubare muto w’abakaraba intoki unashobora guterwa n’umuco wabaye karande wo kudakaraba aho guterwa no kubura isabune cyangwa amazi.
The promotion and advocacy of hand washing with soap can influence policy decisions, raise awareness about the benefits of hand washing and lead to long-term behavior change of the population.

Guteza imbere no gushishikariza abantu gukaraba intoki bakoresheje isabune bishobora kugira icyo bihindura mu gufata ingamba, gutuma abantu bamenya ibyiza byo gukaraba intoki bikanatuma abaturage bahindura imyitwarire by’igihe kirekire.
For this to work effectively, monitoring and evaluation are necessary.
Kugira ngo ibi bikorwe mu buryo bunoze, kubikurikirana no kubisuzuma ni ngombwa.

A systematic review of 70 studies found that community-based approaches are effective at increasing hand washing in LMICs, while social marketing campaigns are less effective.One example for hand washing promotion in schools is the "Three Star Approach" by UNICEF that encourages schools to take simple, inexpensive steps to ensure that students wash their hands with soap, among other hygienic requirements.

Isuzuma ry’ubushakashatsi 70 ryasanze uburyo bushingiye ku baturage butanga umusaruro mu kongera ibikorwa byo gukaraba intoki muri LMICs, mu gihe kumenyekanisha ibikorwa ku mbuga nkoranyambaga bidatanga umusaruro. Urugero rumwe ni aho guteza imbere ibikorwa byo gukaraba intoki mu mashuri ari "Uburyo bwahawe inyenyeri eshatu" na UNICEF mu gushishikariza amashuri gukoresha uburyo bworoheje, budahenze mu guharanira ko abanyeshuri bakaraba intoki bakoresheje isabune, hamwe n’ibindi bikoresho by’isuku.
When minimum standards are achieved, schools can move from one to ultimately three stars.
Iyo ibipimo by’ibanze bigezweho, amashuri ashobora kuva ku nyenyeri imwe akagera ku nyenyeri eshatu.
Building hand washing stations can be a part of hand washing promotion campaigns that are carried out in order to reduce diseases and child mortality.
Kubaka aho abantu bakarabira intoki bishobora kuba bumwe mu buryo bw’ubukangurambaga bwo guteza imbere umuco wo gukaraba intoki bukorwa mu rwego rwo kugabanya indwara n’impfu z’abana.

Global Hand washing Day is another example of an awareness-raising campaign that is trying to achieve behavior change.As a result of the 2019-20 coronavirus pandemic, UNICEF promoted the adoption of a handwashing emoji.

Umunsi mpuzamahanga wo gukaraba intoki ni urundi rugero rw’ubukangurambaga bwo gushishikariza abantu gukaraba intoki mu rwego rwo kugera ku ntego zo guhindura imyitwarire. Bitewe n’icyorezo cya koronavirusi cyo mu 2019-20, UNICEF yateje imbere emoji yo gukaraba intoki.
Few studies have considered the overall cost effectiveness of hand washing in developing countries in relationship to DALYs averted.
Ubushakashatsi buke bwagaragaje muri rusange umusaruro wo gukaraba intoki mu bihugu biri mu nzira y’amajyambere bigereranyijwe n’igipimo cya DALYs.
However, one review suggests that promoting hand washing with soap is significantly more cost-effective than other water and sanitation interventions.
Cyakora, isuzuma rimwe rigaragaza ko guteza imbere umuco wo gukaraba intoki n’isabune byatanze umusaruro kurusha ibindi bikorwa byo gukoresha amazi n’isukura.

The importance of hand washing for human health – particularly for people in vulnerable circumstances like mothers who had just given birth or wounded soldiers in hospitals – was first recognized in the mid 19th century by two pioneers of hand hygiene: the Hungarian physician Ignaz Semmelweis who worked in Vienna, Austria and Florence Nightingale, the English "founder of modern nursing".

Akamaro ko gukaraba intoki mu buzima bwa muntu; by’umwihariko, abantu bafite intege nke nk’ababyeyi bakimara kubyara cyangwa abasirikare bakomerekeye ku rugamba bari mu bitaro, kagaragaye hagati mu kinyejana cya 19 kagaragajwe n’abantu babiri batangije isuku yo mu ntoki: Umuganga w’umunyahongiriya witwa Ignaz Semmelweis wakoraga i Viyene, muri Otirishe na Florence Nightingale, umwongerezakazi "watangije uburyo bushya bwo gukora umwuga w’ubuforomo".
At that time most people still believed that infections were caused by foul odors called miasmas.
Icyo gihe abantu benshi bari bakibwira ko indwara zandura ziterwa n’impumuro mbi yitwa miyazima.

In the 1980s, foodborne outbreaks and healthcare-associated infections led the United States Centers for Disease Control and Prevention to more actively promote hand hygiene as an important way to prevent the spread of infection.

Muri za 1980, ibyorezo biterwa n’ibiribwa n’ubwandu bushamikiye ku buvuzi bwatumye Ikigo cya CDC cy’Amerika kirushaho kongera imbaraga mu gukangurira abantu kugira isuku yo mu ntoki nk’uburyo bw’ingenzi mu kwirinda ikwirakwira ry’indwara.

The outbreak of swine flu in 2009 and the COVID-19 pandemic in 2020 led to increased awareness in many countries of the importance of washing hands with soap to protect oneself from such infectious diseases.

Icyorezo cy’ibicurane by’ingurube cyo mu 2009 n’icyorezo cya COVID-19 cyo mu 2020 byatumye ibihugu birushaho gusobanukirwa neza akamaro ko gukaraba intoki n’isabune mu kwirinda kwandura izo ndwara zandura.
For example, posters with "correct hand washing techniques" were hung up next to hand washing sinks in public toilets and in the toilets of office buildings and airports in Germany.
Urugero, inyandiko nini zanditseho "uburyo bwiza bwo gukaraba intoki" zamanitswe iruhande rwa ravabo zo gukarabiramo intoki mu bwiherero rusange bw’inyubako z’ibiro n’ibibuga by’indege mu Budage.
The phrase "washing one's hands of" something, means declaring one's unwillingness to take responsibility for the thing or share complicity in it.
Ijambo "gukaraba intoki" ku kintu runaka, bisobanura ubushake buke bw’umuntu bwo kutemera ibyo yakoze cyangwa kutemera ubugambanyi muri icyo gikorwa.

It originates from the bible passage in Matthew where Pontius Pilate washed his hands of the decision to crucify Jesus Christ, but has become a phrase with a much wider usage in some English communities.

Byakomotse mu Gitabo cyo muri Bibiliya cya Matayo aho Ponsiyo Pilato yakarabye intoki ze amaze gufata icyemezo cyo kubamba Yezu Kristu, ariko iyo nteruro ikomeza gukoreshwa cyane mu bavuga ururimi rw’Icyongereza.

In Shakespeare's Macbeth, Lady Macbeth begins to compulsively wash her hands in an attempt to cleanse an imagined stain, representing her guilty conscience regarding crimes she had committed and induced her husband to commit.

Mu ikinamico ya Macbeth yanditswe na Shakespeare, Madamazera Macbeth yatangiye kujya akaraba intoki ze mu rwego rwo gukuraho ikizinga yatekerezaga ko afite, bigaragaza ko umutima wamukomangaga ku bw’ibyaha yakoze n’ibyo yatumye umugabo we akora.
It has also been found that people, after having recalled or contemplated unethical acts, tend to wash hands more often than others, and tend to value hand washing equipment more.

Byagaragaye ko abantu, iyo bamaze kwibuka cyangwa gutekereza gukora ibikorwa bidakwiye, bagerageza gukaraba intoki inshuro nyinshi kurusha abandi, no guha agaciro ibikoresho byo gukaraba intoki kurusha ibindi.
Furthermore, those who are allowed to wash their hands after such a contemplation are less likely to engage in other "cleansing" compensatory actions, such as volunteering.
Kandi, abemererwa gukaraba intoki bamaze gutekereza ibyo bikorwa bibi bakunda kutongera gukora ibindi bikorwa byo "kwisukura" bihana nko gukora ibikorwa by’ubukorerabushake.

Religions prescribe hand washing for both hygienic and symbolic purposes.Symbolic hand washing, using water but no soap to wash hands, is a part of ritual hand washing featured in many religions, including Bahá'í Faith, Hinduism, tevilah and netilat yadayim in Judaism, Lavabo in Christianity, and Wudhu in Islam.Religions also prescribe hygienic hand washing, especially after certain actions.

Hari amadini asaba ko abayoboke bayo bakaraba intoki mu rwego rw’isuku no kugaragaza imigenzo y’idini. Gukaraba intoki hagaragazwa imigenzo y’idini, hakoreshejwe amazi gusa nta sabune ukaraba intoki, ni kimwe mu bigize umuco uranga amadini menshi atandukanye, harimo ababahayi, abahindu, abatevira n’abanetirati yadayimu mu Idini rya Kiyahudi, ravabo mu bemera Yezu, na wudu muri Isiramu. Amadini anasaba abayoboke bayo kugira isuku bakaraba intoki, cyane cyane nyuma yo gukora ibikorwa byihariye.
Hinduism, Judaism and Islam mandate washing of hands after using the toilet.
Abahindu, Idini rya Kiyahudi na Isiramu bategeka gukaraba intoki nyuma yo kuva mu bwiherero.
And, Hinduism, Buddhism, Sikhism, Judaism and Islam mandate washing of hands before and after every meal.
Kandi Abahindu, Ababuda, Abasiki, Idini rya Kiyahudi na Isiramu bategeka gukaraba intoki mbere na nyuma ya buri gufata amafunguro.
Impact of the 2019–20 coronavirus pandemic on education
Ingaruka z’icyorezo cya koronavirusi cyo mu 2019–20 ku burezi
The 2019–20 coronavirus pandemic has affected educational systems worldwide, leading to the widespread closures of schools and universities.
Icyorezo cya koronavirusi cyo mu 2019–20 cyagize ingaruka ku burezi ku rwego rw’isi, bituma amashuri na za kaminuza bifungwa ahantu henshi.
As of 8 April 2020, approximately 1.716 billion learners have been affected due to school closures in response to COVID-19.
Kugeza ku ya 8 Mata 2020, hafi abanyeshuri miriyari 1,716 bagizweho ingaruka n’ifungwa ry’amashuri mu kurwanya COVID-19.
According to UNESCO monitoring, 188 countries have implemented nationwide closures and 5 have implemented local closures, impacting about 99.4% of the world's student population.

Hakurikijwe ikurikiranabikorwa rya UNESCO, ibihugu 188 byashyizeho ingamba zo gufunga amashuri yose ku rwego rw’igihugu naho ibihugu 5 byo bifunga amashuri yo mu gace karangwamo icyorezo, bigira ingaruka ku banyeshuri 99,4% bo ku isi.

On 23 March 2020, Cambridge International Examinations (CIE) released a statement announcing the cancellation of Cambridge IGCSE, Cambridge O Level, Cambridge International AS & A Level, Cambridge AICE Diploma, and Cambridge Pre-U examinations for the May/June 2020 series across all countries.

Ku ya 23 Werurwe 2020, Urwego rwa CIE rwatangaje ko ruhagaritse ibizamini by’Icyongereza bya Cambridge IGCSE, Cambridge O Level, Cambridge International AS & A Level, Cambridge AICE Diploma, na Cambridge Pre-U byagombaga gukorwa muri Gicurasi/Kamena 2020 mu bihugu byose.
International Baccalaureate exams have also been cancelled.School closures impact not only students, teachers, and families, but have far-reaching economic and societal consequences.
Ibizamini bya International Baccalaureate na byo byarahagaritswe. Ifungwa ry’amashuri ntiryagize ingaruka gusa ku banyeshuri, abarimu n’imiryango, ahubwo ryanagize ingaruka ku bukungu n’imibereho.

School closures in response to COVID-19 have shed light on various social and economic issues, including student debt, digital learning, food insecurity, and homelessness, as well as access to childcare, health care, housing, internet, and disability services.

Ifungwa ry’amashuri mu rwego rwo kurwanya COVID-19 ryagaragaje ibibazo by’imibereho n’ubukungu, harimo inguzanyo zihabwa abanyeshuri, kwiga hakoreshejwe ikoranabuhanga, kutabona ibiribwa bihagije no kubura aho abantu baba ndetse no kubasha kwita ku bana, ubuvuzi, amacumbi, interineti na serivisi zigenewe abafite ubumuga.

The impact was more severe for disadvantaged children and their families, causing interrupted learning, compromised nutrition, childcare problems, and consequent economic cost to families who could not work.In response to school closures, UNESCO recommended the use of distance learning programmes and open educational applications and platforms that schools and teachers can use to reach learners remotely and limit the disruption of education.

Ingaruka zishobora gukomera ku bana n’imiryango yabo ikennye, bagahura n’ibibazo byo guhagarika kwigai, imirire mibi, ibibazo byo kurera abana n’ingaruka z’ubukungu ku miryango idashobora gukora. Mu guhangana n’ibibazo by’ifungwa ry’amashuri, UNESCO isaba ko hakoreshwa gahunda zo kwiga hakoreshejwe iyakure no gufungura porogaramu n’imbuga byo kwigiraho amashuri n’abarimu bakoresha mu kugera ku banyeshuri hakoreshejwe ikoranabuhanga no kugabanya ibyatera inkomyi mu burezi.

Efforts to stem the spread of COVID-19 through non-pharmaceutical interventions and preventive measures such as social-distancing and self-isolation have prompted the widespread closure of primary, secondary, and tertiary schooling in over 100 countries.Previous outbreaks of infectious diseases have prompted widespread school closings around the world, with varying levels of effectiveness.

Ibikorwa byo gukumira ikwirakwira rya COVID-19 hakoreshejwe ingamba zo kurwanya ubwandu hadakoreshejwe imiti nko kwirinda kwegerana no kwishyira mu kato byatumye mu bice byinshi hafungwa amashuri abanza, ayisumbuye n’amashuri makuru mu bihugu birenga 100. Ibyorezo by’indwara byabayeho mbere na byo byatumye amashuri afungwa ku isi, ariko umusaruro bitanga ugenda utandukana.
Mathematical modelling has shown that transmission of an outbreak may be delayed by closing schools.
Ibipimo bishingiye ku mibare byagaragaje ko ikwirakwira ry’icyorezo rishobora gutinzwa n’ifungwa ry’amashuri.
However, effectiveness depends on the contacts children maintain outside of school.
Ariko, gutanga umusaruro biterwa n’abo abanyeshuri bahura na bo batari ku ishuri.
School closures may be effective when enacted promptly.
Ifungwa ry’amashuri rishobora gutanga umusaruro igihe bikozwe ako kanya.
If school closures occur late relative to an outbreak, they are less effective and may not have any impact at all.
Iyo amashuri afunzwe nyuma icyorezo cyaramaze kwaduka, bitanga umusaruro muke kandi binashobora no kutagira icyo bidahindura na gato.
Additionally, in some cases, the reopening of schools after a period of closure has resulted in increased infection rates.
Kandi, rimwe na rimwe kongera gufungura amashuri amaze igihe afunzwe byagiye byongera umubare w’abandura.

As closures tend to occur concurrently with other interventions such as public gathering bans, it can be difficult to measure the specific impact of school closures.During the 1918-1919 influenza pandemic in the United States, school closures and public gathering bans were associated with lower total mortality rates.

Ifungwa ry’amashuri rigomba kujyana n’ibindi bikorwa nko kubuza abantu guterana, bishobora kuba bikomeye kumenya impinduka ifungwa ry’amashuri ryazanye. Mu cyorezo cyo mu 1918-1919 cyateye Amerika, ifungwa ry’amashuri no kubuza abantu guterana byatumye igiteranyo cy’abapfa kigabanuka.
Cities that implemented such interventions earlier had greater delays in reaching peak mortality rates.
Imijyi yashyize mu bikorwa izo ngamba mbere yagiye itinda kugera ku mubare munini w’abapfa.
Schools closed for a median duration of 4 weeks according to a study of 43 US cities' response to the Spanish Flu.
Amashuri yafunzwe mu gihe cy’ibyumweru 4 hakurikijwe ubushakashatsi bwakozwe ku mijyi 43 y’Amerika mu kurwanya icyorezo cy’ibicurane byo muri Esipanye.

School closures were shown to reduce morbidity from the Asian flu by 90% during the 1957–58 outbreak, and up to 50% in controlling influenza in the US, 2004–2008.Multiple countries successfully slowed the spread of infection through school closures during the 2009 H1N1 Flu pandemic.

Ifungwa ry’amashuri ryerekanye ko ryagabanyije impfu mu bicurane byo muri Aziya ho 90% mu cyorezo cyateye mu 1957–58, no kugeza kuri 50% mu kurwanya ibicurane muri Amerika mu 2004–2008. Ibihugu byinshi byabashije kugabanya ikwirakwira ry’ubwandu binyuze mu gufunga amashuri mu cyorezo cya 2009 H1N1.

School closures in the city of Oita, Japan, were found to have successfully decreased the number of infected students at the peak of infection; however closing schools was not found to have significantly decreased the total number of infected students.

Ifungwa ry’amashuri mu mujyi wa Oita, mu Buyapani, ryagaragaje ko ryatanze umusaruro mu kugabanya umubare w’abanyeshuri banduye igihe abantu banduraga ari benshi; ariko, ifungwa ry’amashuri ryagaragaye ko ritagize icyo rihindura kigaragara ku giteranyo cy’umubare w’abanyeshuri banduye.
Mandatory school closures and other social distancing measures were associated with a 29% to 37% reduction in influenza transmission rates.
Ifungwa ry’amashuri ritegetswe n’izindi ngamba zo kwirinda kwegerana byagize uruhare mu igabanuka ryo kuva kuri 29% kugeza kuri 37% by’imibare y’ikwirakwira ry’ibicurane.
Early school closures in the United States delayed the peak of the 2009 H1N1 Flu pandemic.
Gufunga amashuri hakiri kare muri Amerika byatindije ubwiyongere bukabije bw’icyorezo cy’ibicurane cya 2009 H1N1.

Despite the overall success of closing schools, a study of school closures in Michigan found that "district level reactive school closures were ineffective."During the swine flu outbreak in 2009 in the UK, in an article titled "Closure of schools during an influenza pandemic" published in the Lancet Infectious Diseases, a group of epidemiologists endorsed the closure of schools in order to interrupt the course of the infection, slow further spread and buy time to research and produce a vaccine.

Nubwo gufunga amashuri byagiye bitanga umusaruro, ubushakashatsi ku ifungwa ry’amashuri muri Michigan ryasanze “gufunga amashuri ku rwego rw’akarere bitarigeze bitanga umusaruro”. Mu gihe cy’icyorezo cy’ibicurane by’ibiguruka cyo mu 2009 mu Bwongereza, umutwe w’inkuru "Ifungwa ry’amashuri mu gihe cy’icyorezo cy’ibicurane" yatangajwe mu kinyamakuru cya Lancet Infectious Diseases, itsinda ry’impuguke mu by’ibyorezo ryemeje ko gufunga amashuri mu kwirinda ikwirakwira ry’icyorezo, birushaho kugabanya ikwirakwira ryacyo bikanatanga umwanya wo gushakisha no gukora urukingo.

Having studied previous influenza pandemics including the 1918 flu pandemic, the influenza pandemic of 1957 and the 1968 flu pandemic, they reported on the economic and workforce effect school closure would have, particularly with a large percentage of doctors and nurses being women, of whom half had children under the age of 16.

Kuba harakozwe ubushakashatsi ku cyorezo cy’ibicurane byateye harimo icyorezo cy’ibicurane cyo mu 1918, icyorezo cy’ibicurane cyo mu 1957 n’icyorezo cyo mu 1968, bwatangaje ko ifungwa ry’amashuri ryagize ingaruka ku bukungu n’abakozi; by’umwihariko, ijanisha rinini ry’abaganga n’abaforomo b’abagore bari bafite abana batarengeje imyaka 16.
They also looked at the dynamics of the spread of influenza in France during French school holidays and noted that cases of flu dropped when schools closed and re-emerged when they re-opened.

Hanarebwe uko icyorezo gikwirakwira mu Bufaransa mu kiruhuko cy’amashuri mu Bufaransa maze hatangazwa ko umubare w’abarwaye ibicurane wagabanutse amashuri afunzwe maze wongera kwiyongera amashuri afunguye.

They noted that when teachers in Israel went on strike during the flu season of 1999–2000, visits to doctors and the number of respiratory infections dropped by more than a fifth and more than two fifths respectively.

Hatangajwe ko ubwo abarimu bo muri Isiraheli bajyaga mu myigaragambyo mu gihe cy’icyorezo cy’ibicurane cyo mu 1999–2000, abajyaga kwa muganga n’umubare w’ubwandu bw’indwara zo mu buhumekero wagabanutseho kimwe cya gatanu na bibiri bya gatanu.

For schools and childcare facilities, the U.S. Centers for Disease Control and Prevention recommends short-term closure to clean or disinfect if an infected person has been in a school building regardless of community spread.
Ikigo cya CDC gisaba ko amashuri n’amarerero bifungwa by’igihe gito cyangwa hagaterwamo umuti wica udukoko igihe habonetse umuntu wanduye ku ishuri hatitawe ku kuba umuntu yakwanduza mugenzi we.

When there is minimal to moderate community transmission, social distancing strategies can be implemented such as cancelling field trips, assemblies, and other large gatherings such as physical education or choir classes or meals in a cafeteria, increasing the space between desks, staggering arrival and dismissal times, limiting nonessential visitors, and using a separate health office location for children with flu-like symptoms.

Nubwo haba hari umubare muto cyangwa munini wo kwanduzanya hagati y’abantu, ingamba zo kwirinda kwegerana zishobora gukurikizwa hahagarikwa ingendoshuri n’amateraniro y’abantu benshi nk’imyitozo ngororamubiri cyangwa amasomo yo kuririmba muri korari cyangwa gufatira amafunguro muri kantine, kongera umwanya hagati y’intebe n’indi, gusiga umwanya hari uwinjiye cyangwa usohotse, kureka ibyo gusura bitari ngombwa no gukoresha ivuriro riri ahandi ku bana bagaragaza ibimenyetso bimeze nk’iby’ibicurane.
When there is substantial transmission in the local community, in addition to social distancing strategies, extended school dismissals may be considered.
Igihe hari kwanduzanya cyane hagati y’abantu, usibye ingamba zo kwirinda kwegerana, hashobora gusabwa ko amashuri akomeza gufungwa.
On 26 January, China instituted measures to contain the COVID-19 outbreak which included extending the Spring Festival holiday to contain the outbreak.
Ku ya 26 Mutarama, Ubushinwa bwatanze amabwiriza yo gukumira icyorezo cya COVID-19 harimo no kongera igihe cy’ikiruhuko cy’Iserukiramuco rya Spring Festival mu kurwanya icyorezo.
Universities and schools around the country closed.
Kaminuza n’amashuri mu gihugu yarafunzwe.
On 23 February, Iran's Ministry of Health announced the closure of universities, higher educational institutions and schools in several cities and provinces.
Ku wa 23 Gashyantare, Minisitiri w’ubuzima wa Irani yatangaje ko kaminuza, amashuri makuru, amashuri abanza n’ayisumbuye bifunzwe mu mijyi myinshi no mu ntara nyinshi.
On 3 March, UNESCO released the first global numbers on school closures and affected students.
Ku ya 3 Werurwe, UNESCO yasohoye imibare ya mbere yo ku rwego rw’isi ku ifungwa ry’amashuri n’abanyeshuri byagizeho ingaruka.
It reported that 13 countries had enacted preventive measures including the temporary closure of schools and universities, impacting 290.5 million students around the world.
Hatangajwe ko ibihugu 13 byashyizeho ingamba zo kurwanya icyorezo harimo gufunga by’agateganyo amashuri na kaminuza, bigira ingaruka ku banyeshuri miriyoni 290,5 ku isi.
In reaction, UNESCO called on countries to support affected students and families and facilitate large-scale inclusive distance learning programmes.
Bityo, UNESCO isaba ibihugu gufasha abanyeshuri n’imiryango bagezweho n’ingaruka no koroshya uburyo bugera kuri benshi ntawuhejwe bwa gahunda zo kwiga hakoreshejwe iyakure.
On 4 March, the Italian government ordered the full closure of all schools and universities nationwide as Italy reached 100 deaths.
Ku ya 4 Werurwe, Leta y’Ubutaliyani yategetse ko amashuri yose na kaminuza zose bifungwa mu gihugu aho mu Butaliyani hari hamaze gupfa abantu 100.
In doing so, Italy became one of 22 countries on three continents which had announced or implemented school closures.
Bityo, Ubutaliyani buba kimwe mu bihugu 22 byo ku migabane itatu byatangaje cyangwa byafunze amashuri.
On 5 March, the majority of learners affected by COVID-19 emergency measures were located in China, with 233 million learners affected, followed by Japan at 16.5 million and Iran at 14.5 million.

Ku ya 5 Werurwe, umubare munini w’abanyeshuri wagizweho n’ingaruka z’ingamba zo kurwanya icyorezo cya COVID-19 bari baherereye mu Bushinwa, aho miriyoni 233 z’abanyeshuri bagizweho ingaruka, bukurikirwa n’Ubuyapani bufite miriyoni 16,5 na Irani ifite miriyoni14,5.
By 10 March, one in five students worldwide was "staying away from school due to the COVID-19 crisis" while another one in four was barred from higher education institutions.
Kugeza ku ya 10 Werurwe, umwe mu banyeshuri batanu ku isi "ntiyageraga ku ishuri kubera icyorezo cya COVID-19" mu gihe umwe muri bane yabujijwe kutagera mu mashuri makuru.
On 13 March, governments in 49 countries announced or implemented school closures, including 39 countries which closed schools nationwide and 22 countries with localised school closures.

Ku ya 13 Werurwe, leta zo mu bihugu 49 zatangaje cyangwa zashyize mu bikorwa ingamba zo gufunga amashuri, harimo ibihugu 39 byafunze amashuri mu gihugu hose naho ibihugu 22 bifunga amashuri mu duce tumwe na tumwe.
By 16 March, this figure increased from 49 to 73 countries according to UNESCO.
Kugeza ku ya 16 Werurwe, iyi mibare yariyongeye iva ku bihugu 49 igera ku bihugu 73 hakurikijwe ibyatangajwe na UNESCO.

By 19 March, 50% of students worldwide were affected by school closures, corresponding to nationwide closures in 102 countries and local closures in 11 countries affecting 850 million children and youth.

Kugeza ku ya 19 Werurwe, 50% by’abanyeshuri bo ku isi bagizweho ingaruka n’ifungwa ry’amashuri, bijyanye n’ifungwa ry’amashuri mu bihugu 102 no gufunga amashuri mu bice bimwe na bimwe mu bihugu 11 byakomeje kugira ingaruka kuri miriyoni 850 z’abana n’urubyiruko.
By 20 March, over 70% of the world's learners were impacted by closures, with 124 country-wide school closures.
Kugeza ku ya 20 Werurwe, abanyeshuri barenga 70% ku isi bagizweho ingaruka n’ifungwa ry’amashuri, aho mu bihugu 124 amashuri yafunzwe ku rwego rw’igihugu.

On 23 March, all Nigerian school were found to have been closed down by Nigerian government, markets as well as companies were closed down and children were forbidden by parents to step out of their homes.
Ku ya 23 Werurwe, amashuri yose yo muri Nijeriya yafunzwe na leta ya Nijeriya, amasoko n’amasosiyete birafungwa n’abana babuzwa n’ababyeyi babo kuva mu rugo.
On 26 March, all New Zealand schools and universities have been closed down across the country.
Ku ya 26 Werurwe, amashuri yose na kaminuza zose byo muri Nuveli Zelande byarafunzwe ku rwego rw’igihugu.
The government has imposed a two-week holiday, allowing schools to transition to forms of distant teaching as soon as possible.
Leta yategetse ko hajyaho ikiruhuko cy’ibyumweru bibiri, bituma amashuri ahindura akoresha uburyo bw’iyakure.
Universities have closed for one week, but resumed with online teaching afterwards.
Kaminuza zafunzwe icyumweru kimwe, ariko ziza gusubukura amasomo hakoreshejwe iyakure.
Other school services remain open, but teaching is restricted to distant learning.
Izindi serivisi z’ishuri zakomeje gufungura, ariko kwigisha bikomeza gukorwa hakoreshejwe iyakure.
By 27 March, nearly 90 percent of the world's student population was out of class.
Kugeza ku ya 27 Werurwe, hafi 90 ku ijana by’abanyeshuri bo ku isi ntibari bakiga.
Regions with schools remaining open included Taiwan, Singapore, Australia, Sweden, and some U.S. states.
Uturere dufite amashuri agifunguye harimo Tayiwani, Singapuru, Ositaraliya, Suwede na zimwe muri leta zo muri Amerika.
By 29 March, more than 1.5 billion children and other students were affected by nationwide school closures.
Kugeza ku ya 29 Werurwe, abana n’abandi banyeshuri barenga miriyari 1,5 bagizweho ingaruka n’ifungwa ry’amashuri mu guhugu.
Others were disrupted by localized closures.
Abandi bagirwaho ingaruka n’ifungwa ry’amashuri mu bice bimwe na bimwe.
Until April 6, holidays were extended in all secondary schools of Turkmenistan.
Kugeza ku ya 6 Mata, ibiruhuko byarongerewe ku mashuri yisumbuye yose yo muri Turikimenisitani.
An order signed by the Ministry of Education as a preventative measure aims to prevent the spread of respiratory diseases in connection with the WHO coronavirus pandemic.
Itegeko ryashizweho umukono na Minisitiri w’uburezi mu kurwanya icyorezo rigamije gukumira ikwirakwira ry’indwara z’ubuhumekero zifite aho zihuriye n’icyorezo cya koronavirusi cyatangajwe na OMS.

10 countries have localised schools closures, UNESCO estimates 473,933,356 learners are potentially at risk (pre-primary to upper-secondary education) and 77,938,904 learners are potentially at risk in tertiary education.

Ibihugu 10 byagiye bifunga amashuri mu bice bimwe na bimwe, UNESCO itangaza ko abanyeshuri 473 933 356 bafite ibyago ari abo mu mashuri y’incuke kugeza mu cyiciro cya kabiri cy’amashuri yisumbuye, naho abanyeshuri 77 938 904 bafite ibyago ni abo mu mashuri makuru na za kaminuza.

Note: Figures correspond to total number of learners enrolled at pre-primary, primary, lower-secondary, and upper-secondary levels of education [ISCED levels 0 to 3], as well as at tertiary education levels [ISCED levels 5 to 8] who could be affected should localised closures become countrywide.

Icyitonderwa: Iyo mibare ihuye n’igiteranyo cy’abanyeshuri biyandikishije mu mashuri y’incuke, amashuri abanza, icyiciro cya mbere cy’amashuri yisumbuye, icyiciro cya kabiri cy’amashuri yisumbuye [ibipimo bya ISCED kuva kuri 0 kugera kuri 3], n’abo mu mashuri makuru na za kaminuza [ibipimo bya ISCED kuva kuri 5 kugeza kuri 8] bashobora kugirwaho ingaruka n’ifungwa ry’amashuri ubu rikorwa hose mu gihugu.
Enrolment figures based on latest UNESCO Institute of Statistics data.
Imibare y’abiyandikishije ishingiye ku makuru y’Ikigo cy’ibarurishamibare cya UNESCO.
School closures in response to the COVID-19 pandemic have shed a light on numerous issues affecting access to education, as well as broader socio-economic issues.
Ifungwa ry’amashuri ryakozwe mu rwego rwo kurwanya icyorezo cya COVID-19 ryagaragaje ibibazo bigira ingaruka ku kubona uburezi n’ibibazo bikomeye by’imibereho n’ubukungu.

As of March 12, more than 370 million children and youth are not attending school because of temporary or indefinite country wide school closures mandated by governments in an attempt to slow the spread of COVID-19.

Kugeza ku ya 12 Werurwe, abana n’urubyiruko barenga miriyoni 370 ntibajya ku ishuri kubera ifungwa ry’igihe gito cyangwa rya burundu ry’amashuri ku rwego rw’igihugu ritegetswe na leta mu kugabanya ikwirakwira ry’icyorezo cya COVID-19.
As of 29 March, nearly 90% of the world's learners were impacted by closures.Even when school closures are temporary, it carries high social and economic costs.
Kugeza ku ya 29 Werurwe, hafi 90% by’abanyeshuri bo ku isi bagizweho ingaruka n’ifungwa ry’amashuri. Nubwo amashuri yafunzwe by’igihe gito, byagize ingaruka zikomeye ku mibereho n’ubukungu.

The disruptions they cause affect people across communities, but their impact is more severe for disadvantaged children and their families including interrupted learning, compromised nutrition, childcare problems and consequent economic cost to families who cannot work.

Iryo fungwa ryagize ingaruka ku bantu mu bice bitandukanye, ariko ingaruka zirushaho gukomera ku bana n’imiryango yabo ikennye harimo ihagarikwa ry’amasomo, imirire mibi, kurera abana n’ibibazo by’ubukungu ku miryango idakora.
Working parents are more likely to miss work when schools close in order to take care of their children, incurring wage loss in many instances and negatively impacting productivity.
Birashoboka cyane ko ababyeyi bakora basibaakazi igihe amashuri afunze kugira ngo bite ku bana babo, bakanabura umushahara bitewe n’impamvu zitandukanye bikanagira ingaruka mbi ku musaruro wabo.
Localised school closures place burdens on schools as parents and officials redirect children to schools that are open.
Ifungwa ry’amashuri mu bice bimwe na bimwe ryashyize umutwaro ku mashuri kuko ababyeyi n’abayobozi bohereje abana ku mashuri agifunguye.
Women often represent a large share of health-care workers and often cannot attend work because of childcare obligations that result from school closures.
Akenshi abagore ni bo bagize umubare munini w’abakora mu nzego z’ubuvuzi kandi akenshi ntibashobora kujya ku kazi kubera inshingano zo kurera abana bitewe n’ifungwa ry’amashuri.
This means that many medical professionals are not at the facilities where they are most needed during a health crisis.
Bivuze ko abaganga benshi batari mu bigo bakoramo aho bakenewe cyane muri iki gihe cy’icyorezo.
Lack of access to technology or fast, reliable internet access can prevent students in rural areas and from disadvantaged families.
Kutagera ku ikoranabuhanga cyangwa kubona interineti yihuta, idacika byabuza abanyeshuri bo mu byaro banaturuka mu miryango ikennye kuba bakurikirana amasomo hakoreshejwe iyakure.
Lack of access to technology or good internet connectivity is an obstacle to continued learning, especially for students from disadvantaged families.
Kutabona ikoranabuhanga cyangwa interineti imeze neza ni imbogamizi ku gukomeza kwiga; by’umwihariko, ku banyeshuri baturuka mu miryango ikennye.

In response to school closures caused by COVID-19, UNESCO recommends the use of distance learning programmes and open educational applications and platforms that schools and teachers can use to reach learners remotely and limit the disruption of education.To aid in slowing the transmission of COVID-19, hundreds of libraries have temporarily closed.

Mu ifungwa ry’amashuri ritewe n’icyorezo cya COVID-19, UNESCO isaba ko hakoreshwa gahunda zo kwiga hakoreshejwe iyakure no gufungura porogaramu n’imbuga by’uburezi amashuri n’abarimu bashobora gukoresha mu kugera ku banyeshuri hakoreshejwe iyakure no kugabanya ihungabana ry’uburezi. Mu gufasha kugabanya icyorezo cya COVID-19, amagana y’amasomero yarafunze by’agateganyo.
In the United States, numerous major cities announced public library closures, including Los Angeles, San Francisco, Seattle, and New York City, affecting 221 libraries.
Muri Amerika, imijyi myinshi ikomeye yatangaje ko ifunze amasomero, harimo Los Angeles, San Francisco, Seattle na New York City, bigira ingaruka mu masomero 221.
For students without internet at home, this increases the difficulty of keeping up with distance learning.
Ku banyeshuri badafite interineti mu rugo, byongereye ingorane zo gukomeza kwiga hakoreshejwe iyakure.
School closures puts a strain on parents and guardians to provide childcare and manage distance learning while children are out of school.
Ifungwa ry’amashuri riteza ibibazo ababyeyi n’abarera abana mu rwego rwo kubarera no gucunga uko biga hakoreshejwe iyakure mu gihe abana batari ku ishuri.

In the absence of alternative options, working parents often leave children alone when schools close and this can lead to risky behaviours, including increased influence of peer pressure and substance abuse.

Mu gihe nta yandi mahitamo ahari, akenshi ababyeyi bakora basiga abana bonyine igihe amashuri afunze kandi bishobora gutuma bagira imyitwarire mibi, harimo kwiyongera mu guhozwa ku gitutu n’urungano no gukoresha ibiyobyabwenge.
Many children worldwide rely on free or discounted meals at schools.
Abana benshi ku isi bagendera ku biribwa byo ku ishuri bitangirwa ubuntu cyangwa bya make.

When schools close, nutrition is compromised.Nutrition plays a critical role in cognitive development and academic performance for children.In Washington State, around 45% of the states 1.1 million students enrolled in traditional public and charter schools qualify for subsidised school meals.

Iyo amashuri afunze, imirire irahungabana. Imirire igira uruhare rukomeye mu mikurire y’ubwonko n’imitsindire y’abana mu mashuri. Muri leta ya Washington, hafi 45% by’abanyeshuri miriyoni 1,1 bo muri iyo leta biyandikishije mu mashuri ya leta asanzwe n’amashuri yigenga bahabwa ibiribwa bitangirwa ku ishuri.

At least 520,000 students and their families may be affected by food insecurity as a result of school closures.School lunch programmes are the second-biggest anti-hunger initiative in the United States after food stamps.

Byibuze abanyeshuri 520 000 n’imiryango yabo bashobora kugirwaho ingaruka no kutihaza mu biribwa bitewe n’ifungwa ry’amashuri. Gahunda yo gutanga amafunguro ya saa sita ku mashuri ni yo gahunda ya kabiri nini mu kurwanya inzara muri Amerika nyuma ya gahunda y’amakarita y’ibiryo.

Every year, nearly 30 million children rely on schools to provide free or low-cost meals including breakfast, lunch, snacks, and even dinner.In Alabama, where state-wide school closures as of 18 March have affected over 720,000 students, the state Superintendent announced that staff in schools disproportionately affected by poverty would create meal distribution networks to provide food for students who rely on school lunches.

Buri mwaka, abana hafi miriyoni 30 bagendera ku mashuri kubera ko atanga ibiribwa by’ubuntu cyangwa ku mafaranga make harimo ibya amafunguro ya mugitondo, saa sita, amafunguro yoroheje n’ibya nimugoroba. Muri Alabama, ahafunzwe amashuri yose muri leta tariki ya 18 Werurwe byagize ingaruka ku banyeshuri 720 000, umuyobozi mukuru ushinzwe amashuri muri leta yatangaje ko abakozi bakora mu mashuri bagerwaho ingaruka z’ubukene zitandukanye bafashwa hakanashyirwaho uburyo bwo kugemurira ibiribwa abanyeshuri bagendera ku biribwa bitangirwa ku mashuri.
School closures negatively impact student learning outcomes.
Ifungwa ry’amashuri ryagize ingaruka mbi ku musaruro w’imyigire y’abanyeshuri.
Schooling provides essential learning and when schools close, children and youth are deprived opportunities for growth and development.
Imyigire itanga ubumenyi bw’ibanze rero iyo amashuri afunze, abana n’urubyiruko bavutswa amahirwe y’imikurire no kunguka ubwenge.

The disadvantages are disproportionate for under-privileged learners who tend to have fewer educational opportunities beyond school.Student drop-out rates tend to increase as an effect of school closures due to the challenge of ensuring all students return to school once school closures ends.

Ingaruka ziratandukanye ku banyeshuri bafite ibibazo harimo no kugira amahirwe make yo kubona uburezi batari ku ishuri. Imibare y’abava mu ishuri ishobora kwiyongera kubera ingaruka z’ifungwa ry’amashuri bitewe n’imbogamizi zo gukora ku buryo abanyeshuri bose basubira ku ishuri ifungwa ry’amashuri rirangiye.
This is especially true of protracted closures.Schools are hubs of social activity and human interaction.
Ibi ni ukuri koko bitewe no gukomeza gufunga amashuri. Amashuri ni yo mapfundo y’ibikorwa by’imibereho no kungurana ibitekerezo.

When schools are closed, many children and youth miss out of on social contact that is essential to learning and development.When schools close parents are often asked to facilitate the learning of children at home and can struggle to perform this task.

Iyo amashuri afunzwe, abana benshi n’urubyiruko babura amahirwe yo gushyikirana bikaba ari ingenzi mu myigire n’imikurire y’ubwonko. Iyo amashuri afunzwe akenshi ababyeyi basaba gufashwa mu myigire y’abana mu rugo no guhangana no gukora aka kazi.
This is especially true for parents with limited education and resources.
By’umwihariko, ni byo koko kuba ababyeyi bafite ubushozi buke n’ibyo bifashisha bike.
Potential impacts of school closures and reliance on distance learning are not addressed in federal acts of legislation at this time.
Ibibazo by’ingaruka zo gufunga amashuri no kwishingira kwiga hakoreshejwe iyakure ntibikemurwa n’ingamba za leta muri iki gihe.
Formal education — as opposed to informal education or non-formal education — tends to refer to schools, colleges, universities and training institutions.
Uburezi buzwi (butandukanye n’uburezi butazwi cyangwa uburezi butemewe) bushaka kwibanda ku mashuri, koleje, kaminuza n’ibigo by’imyuga.

A 1974 report by the World Bank defined formal education as the following:Formal education: the hierarchically structured, chronologically graded ‘education system’, running from primary school through the university and including, in addition to general academic studies, a variety of specialised programmes and institutions for full-time technical and professional training.The majority of data collected on the number of students and learners impacted by COVID-19 has been calculated based on the closure of formal education systems.

Raporo yo mu 1974 ya Banki y’isi yasobanuye uburezi bwo mu mashuri nk’uburyo bukurikira: uburyo bunoze bukurikirana buva ku cyiciro kimwe bujya ku kindi hatangwa amanota mu ‘myigishirize’, kuva mu mashuri abanza kugera muri kaminuza kandi harimo n’amasomo rusange, porogaramu z’amasomo yihariye n’ibigo by’amashuri bitanga amasomo ya tekiniki n’imyuga. Amakuru menshi yakusanyijwe ku banyeshuri bagizweho ingaruka na COVID-19 yabazwe hashingiwe ku ifungwa ry’amashuri.

The UNESCO Institute for Statistics provides figures on students impacted by COVID-19 corresponding to the number of learners enrolled at pre-primary, primary, lower-secondary, and upper-secondary levels of education [ISCED levels 0 to 3], as well as at tertiary education levels [ISCED levels 5 to 8].

Ikigo cy’ibarurishamibare cya UNESCO gitanga imibare ku banyeshuri bagizweho ingaruka na COVID-19 ijyanye n’umubare w’abanyeshuri biyandikishije mu mashuri y’incuke, amashuri abanza, icyiciro cya mbere cy’amashuri yisumbuye, icyiciro cya kabiri cy’amashuri yisumbuye [ibipimo bya ISCED kuva kuri 0 kugera kuri 3], n’abo mu mashuri makuru na za kaminuza [ibipimo bya ISCED kuva kuri 3 kugeza kuri 5], ndetse n’abiga mu mashuri makuru na za kaminuza [ibipimo bya ISCED kuva kuri 5 kugeza ku 8].
Early childhood educational programmes are usually designed for children below the age of 3 and may refer to preschools, nursery schools, kindergartens, and some day care programmes.
Gahunda z’imbonezamikurure akenshi ziba zigenewe abana batagejeje imyaka 3 kandi zishobora kuba zijyanye n’amashuri y’inshuke n’amarerero.
While many primary and secondary schools have closed around the world due to COVID-19, measures impacting early childhood educational programmes have varied.
Mu gihe amashuri menshi abanza n’ayisumbuye yafunzwe ku isi bitewe na COVID-19, hafashwe ingamba zitandukanye zigira ingaruka kuri gahunda y’uburezi bw’abana bakiri bato.

In some countries and territories, preschools and day cares are considered necessary services and have not closed in tandem with broader school closure measures.In the United States, the Washington State Department of Children, Youth, and Families encouraged child care and early learning centres to stay open.

Mu bihugu n’uturere tumwe na tumwe, amashuri y’incuke n’amarerero bifatwa nka serivisi z’ibanze kandi zitagomba gufungwa mu gihe cyo gufunga amashuri yose. Muri Amerika, Ishami rya Washington rishinzwe abana, urubyiruko n’imiryango risaba ko amarerero n’ibigo mbonezamikurire byakomeza gufungura.
Some school districts may offer alternative child care options, prioritising the children of first responders and healthcare workers.
Amwe mu mafasi y’ishuri ashobora gutanga ubundi buryo bwo kurera abana, hashyirwa imbere abana b’abakozi bahanganye n’icyorezo n’abakora mu nzego z’ubuvuzi.

The governor of Maryland mandated that specific child care services remain open for the children of emergency personnel while Washington State and California have left it to the discretion of care providers.

Guverineri wa Maryland yatanze itegeko ryihariye risaba ko serivisi zo kurera abana zikomeza gufungurwa ku bana n’abakora muri serivisi z’ubutabazi mu gihe leta ya Washington na California yabirekeye mu maboko y’ubushishozi bw’abatanga serivisi z’ubuvuzi.
California Governor Gavin Newsom explained his state's position, saying “We need our child care facilities, our daycare centers, to operate to absorb the impact of these school closures.”

Guverineri wa California, Gavin Newsom, yasobanuye imimerere ya leta ayoboye, agira ati: “Turifuza ko ibigo birera abana, amarerero, bikomeza gukora kugira ngo bigabanye ingaruka z’ifungwa ry’amashuri”.

Colorado has encouraged the development of "tool kits" for parents to use at home to emulate the lessons children would have received in their early learning programmes.In Japan, Prime Minister Shinzo Abe closed all schools throughout the country until April 8, however, children's daycare facilities were excluded.

Colorado yasabye ikorwa ry' "ibikoresho byifashishwa" bigenewe ababyeyi bakoresha mu rugo kugira ngo bigane amasomo abana babo bakabaye babonera muri gahunda z’imbonezamikurire. Mu Buyapani, Minisitiri w’Intebe, Shinzo Abe, yafunze amashuri mu gihugu hose kugeza ku ya 8 Mata; ariko, amarerero yo ntiyafunzwe.
In early March, five adults associated with a nursing facility for preschool children in Kobe tested positive for coronavirus.
Mu ntangiriro za Werurwe, abantu bakuru batanu bakora mu marerero mu mashuri y’incuke muri Kobe barapimwe basanga bafite koronavirusi.
After testing over one hundred children at the facility, a preschool student was found to be carrying the virus.
Nyuma yo gupima abana barenga ijana muri icyo kigo, umunyeshuri wiga mu ishuri ry’incuke basanze afite virusi.
Primary or elementary education typically consists of the first four to seven years of formal education.
Amashuri abanza cyangwa y’incuke atangwamo uburezi bw’imyaka ine bubanziriza imyaka irindwi y’amashuri abanza.

The International Baccalaureate Organization (IBO) canceled the examinations for its Diploma Programme and Career-related Programme candidates scheduled between 30 April and 22 May 2020, reportedly affecting more than 200,000 students worldwide.

Umuryango wa IBO wahagaritse ibizamini by’abashaka impamyabumenyi n’abiga porogaramu zijyanye no gushakisha akazi byari biteganyijwe kuba ku ya 30 Mata no ku ya 22 Gicurasi 2020, bivugwa ko byagize ingaruka ku banyeshuri barenga 200 000 ku isi.

The IBO stated that it would award candidates their diplomas or certificates based on "their coursework" and "the established assessment expertise, rigor, and quality control already built into the programme."

Umuryango wa IBO watangaje ko uzaha abanyeshuri impamyabumenyi cyangwa impamyabushobozi zabo hashingiwe ku "mikoro y’amasomo" n’"imyitozo, imyigire n’ubumenyi basanzwe bafite muri porogaramu y’amasomo."
Tertiary education, also known as higher education, refers to the non-compulsory educational levels that follow completion of secondary school or high school.
Amashuri makuru na za kaminuza, binitwa amashuri makuru, bivuga icyiciro cy’uburezi kitari itegeko ujyamo ari uko urangije amashuri yisumbuye cyangwa koleje.
Tertiary education is normally taken to include undergraduate and postgraduate education, as well as vocational education and training.
Ubusanzwe, amashuri makuru na za kaminuza birimo uburezi bw’icyiciro cya kabiri n’icya gatatu cya kaminuza ndetse n’uburezi bw’imyuga n’amahugurwa.
Individuals who complete tertiary education generally receive certificates, diplomas, or academic degrees.
Akenshi, abarangiza amashuri makuru na za kaminuza bahabwa impamyabushobozi, impamyabumenyi cyangwa icyemezo cy’ishuri.
Undergraduate education is education conducted after secondary education and prior to post-graduate education, for which the learner is typically awarded a bachelor's degree.

Amashuri y’icyiciro cya kabiri cya kaminuza uyiga urangije amashuri yisumbuye mbere yo kujya mu cyiciro cya gatatu cya kaminuza, aho uwiga akenshi ahabwa impamyabumenyi y’icyiciro cya kabiri cya kaminuza.

Students enrolled in higher education programmes at colleges, universities, and community colleges are often refereed to in countries such as United States as "college students."The closure of colleges and universities has widespread implications for students, faculty, administrators, and the institutions themselves.

Abanyeshuri biyandikishije muri porogaramu z’amashuri makuru muri koleje, kaminuza n’icyiciro cya mbere cya kaminuza akenshi mu bihugu nk’Amerika bitwa "abiga muri koleje." Ifungwa rya koleje na kaminuza byagize ingaruka nini ku banyeshuri, amashami ya kaminuza, abayobozi n’ibigo by’amashuri n’ibigo by’amashuri ubwabyo.
Colleges and universities across the United States have been called upon to issue refunds to students for the cost of tuition and room and board.
Koleje na kaminuza muri Amerika byagiye byasabwe gusubiza abanyeshuri amafaranga y’ishuri, ayishuwe ku byumba n’ayishyuwe n’abiga bacumbika ku ishuri.
In the United States of America, Colleges and universities operate as "mini-cities" which generate significant revenue for cities, states, and regions.
Muri Leta Zunze Ubumwe z’Amerika, koleje na kaminuza bikora nk’"imijyi mito" aho byinjiriza amafaranga menshi imijyi, leta n’uturere.
For example, Princeton University contributed $1.58 billion USD to the New Jersey economy and students spent about $60 million in off-campus spending.
Urugero, kaminuza ya Princeton yinjije miriyari $1,58 mu bukungu bwa New Jersey kandi n’abanyeshuri bakoresha hafi miriyoni $60 mu mafaranga bakoresheje batari kuri kaminuza.

College and university closures have a domino effect on economies with far-reaching implications.According to Linda Bilmes of the Harvard Kennedy School, "local hotels, restaurants, cafes, shops, car rental agencies and other local businesses obtain a significant share of annual revenue from graduation week and college reunions...

Ifungwa rya koleje na za kaminuza bigira ingaruka z’uruhererekane ku bukungu kandi zikomeye. Hakurikijwe ibivugwa na Linda Bilmes wo mu Ishuri rya Harvard Kennedy, “hoteri z’imbere mu gihugu, resitora, aho bacururiza icyayi n’ikawa, amaduka, ibigo bikodesha imodoka n’ibindi bigo by’ubucuruzi by’imbere mu gihugu byinjiza amafaranga buri mwaka aturutse ku birori byo gusoza amashuri n’ibyo kongera kubonana kw’abize muri koleje...

these communities will suffer a lot of economic damage if the colleges remain closed at that time."Small towns which rely on college students to support the local economy and provide labour to local businesses are especially impacted by school closures and the exodus of students from campus.

abo bakora ibyo bikorwa bazagira igihombo gikomeye koleje nizikomeza gufunga”. Imijyi mito igendera ku banyeshuri bo muri koleje kugira ngo zifashe ubukungu bwayo no guha akazi ibikorwa by’ubucuruzi byo muri ako gace by’umwihariko bazagirwaho ingaruka n’ifungwa ry’amashuri no kuba abanyeshuri batakiba muri kaminuza.
In Ithaca, New York, Cornell University students spent at least $4 million a week in Tompkins county.
Muri Ithaca, New York, abanyeshuri ba Kaminuza ya Cornell bakoresheje byibuze miriyoni 4 z’amadorari mu cyumweru mu ntara ya Tompkins.

In the wake of Cornell's decision to keep students home following spring break and transition to virtual instruction, the Mayor of Ithaca called for "immediate and forceful federal action — we will see a horrific economic impact as a result of Cornell University closing."

Nyuma y’icyemezo cya Kaminuza ya Cornell cyo kugumisha abanyeshuri mu rugo mu kiruhuko cyo mu Itumba no guhindura amasomo agatangwa hakoreshejwe iyakure, Meya wa Ithaca yasabye ko “igihugu cyagira icyo gikora kandi gikomeye mu maguru mashya, naho ubundi hazabaho ingaruka zikomeye ku bukungu bitewe no gufunga Kaminuza ya Cornell”.
UNESCO is sharing 10 recommendations during this period:
UNESCO iratanga inama 10 zo kwifashisha muri iki gihe cy’icyorezo:

Examine the readiness and choose the most relevant tools: Decide on the use high-technology and low-technology solutions based on the reliability of local power supplies, internet connectivity, and digital skills of teachers and students.

Gusuzuma uko kwitegura guhangana n’icyorezo bihagaze no guhitamo ibyo ukoresha bya ngombwa: Gufata icyemezo maze ugakoresha ikoranabuhanga ryo mu rwego rwo hejuru n’iryo mu rwego rwo hasi hakurikijwe ubushobozi bw’abatanga serivisi mu gace runaka, interineti n’ubumenyi mu by’ikoranabuhanga bw’abarimu n’abanyeshuri.
This could range through integrated digital learning platforms, video lessons, MOOCs, to broadcasting through radios and TVs.
Bishobora kuba ari imbuga zo kwigiraho, videwo z’amasomo, amasomo yo kuri interineti (MOOC), no gutangaza amasomo hifashishijwe radiyo na televiziyo.

Ensure inclusion of the distance learning programmes: Implement measures to ensure that students including those with disabilities or from low-income backgrounds have access to distance learning programmes, if only a limited number of them have access to digital devices.

Guharanira ko izo gahunda zo kwiga hakoreshejwe iyakure zidaheza: Gushyiraho ingamba zo gukora ku buryo abanyeshuri harimo n’abafite ubumuga cyangwa abakomoka mu miryango ikennye babona gahunda yo kwiga hakoreshejwe iyakure, niba umubare muto muri bo ari wo ushobora kubona ibikoresho by’ikoranabuhanga.
Consider temporarily decentralising such devices from computer labs to families and support them with internet connectivity.
Gushyiraho uburyo bwo kuvana ibyo bikoresho mu mashuri yabugenewe nka mudasobwa maze bigahabwa imiryango kugira ngo biyifashe kubona interineti by’igihe gito.
Protect data privacy and data security: Assess data security when uploading data or educational resources to web spaces, as well as when sharing them with other organisations or individuals.

Kurinda ubuzima bwite bw’amakuru n’umutekano w’amakuru: Kubona umutekano w’amakuru igihe uri kohereza amakuru cyangwa uri kohereza amasomo ku mbuga, ndetse n’igihe uri kubisangiza ibigo cyangwa abantu ku giti cyabo.
Ensure that the use of applications and platforms does not violate students’ data privacy.
Guharanira ko ikoreshwa rya porogaramu n’imbuga bitabangamira ubuzima bwite bw’abanyeshuri.
Prioritize solutions to address psychosocial challenges before teaching: Mobilize available tools to connect schools, parents, teachers, and students with each other.

Gushyira imbere uburyo bwo gukemura imbogamizi z’ubuzima bwo mu mutwe n’imyitwarire mbere yo gutangira kwigisha: Gukoresha ibikoresho bihari byifashishwa mu koroshya imikoranire hagati y’amashuri, ababyeyi, abarimu n’abanyeshuri.
Create communities to ensure regular human interactions, enable social caring measures, and address possible psychosocial challenges that students may face when they are isolated.

Gushyiraho amatsinda afasha mu gutuma abantu bashyikirana ku buryo buhoraho, gushyiraho amatsinda yo gufashanya no gukemura imbogamizi z’ubuzima bwo mu mutwe n’imyitwarire abanyeshuri bashobora kugira igihe bari bonyine.

Plan the study schedule of the distance learning programmes: Organise discussions with stakeholders to examine the possible duration of school closures and decide whether the distance learning programme should focus on teaching new knowledge or enhance students’ knowledge of prior lessons.

Gutegura gahunda zo kwiga hakoreshejwe iyakure: Gutegura ibiganiro n’abafatanyabikorwa mu gusuzuma igihe amashuri ashobora gukomeza gufunga no kwemeza niba gahunda zo kwiga hakoreshejwe iyakure zakwibanda ku kwigisha amasomo mashya cyangwa gusubira mu masomo abanyeshuri bari barize.
Plan the schedule depending on the situation of the affected zones, level of studies, needs of students needs, and availability of parents.
Gushyiraho gahunda hakurikijwe uko ibintu byifashe mu bice byugarijwe n’icyorezo, urwego rw’amasomo, ibyo abanyeshuri bakeneye n’imibonekere y’ababyeyi.
Choose the appropriate learning methodologies based on the status of school closures and home-based quarantines.
Guhitamo uburyo bwo kwiga buboneye hashingiwe ku mimerere yo gufunga amashuri n’akato ko mu rugo.
Avoid learning methodologies that require face-to-face communication.
Kwirinda uburyo bwo kwiga busaba ko abantu babonana imbonankubone.
Provide support to teachers and parents on the use of digital tools: Organise brief training or orientation sessions for teachers and parents as well, if monitoring and facilitation are needed.

Guha ubufasha abarimu n’ababyeyi ku ikoreshwa ry’ibikoresho by’’ikoranabuhanga: Gutegura amahugurwa magufi cyangwa amasomo yo gusobanurira abarimu n’ababyeyi, niba ikurikiranabikorwa n’ubufasha bikenewe.
Help teachers to prepare the basic settings such as solutions to the use of internet data if they are required to provide live streaming of lessons.
Gufasha abarimu gutegura imikorere y’ibanze nko gukoresha interineti niba ari ngombwa kugira ngo batange amasomo ako kanya hakoreshejwe ikoranabuhanga.

Blend appropriate approaches and limit the number of applications and platforms: Blend tools or media that are available for most students, both for synchronous communication and lessons, and for asynchronous learning.

Guhuza uburyo buboneye no kugabanya umubare wa porogaramu n’imbuga: Guhuza ibikoresho cyangwa imiyoboro ihari ku banyeshuri benshi, yaba mu guhuza uburyo bwo guhanahana amakuru n’amasomo ako kanya no kwiga bitari ako kanya.
