Phase II trials are used to establish an initial reading of efficacy and further explore safety in small numbers of people having the disease targeted by the NCE.

Ikiciro cya II k’igerageza gikoreshwa mu kugaragaza iby’ibanze bigaragaza ubushobozi bw’umuti mu kuvura hanyuma hakarebwa ingarua zawo bikorewe ku mubare w’abantu bake bafite ubwandu burimo kwitabwaho na NCE.
Phase III trials are large, pivotal trials to determine safety and efficacy in sufficiently large numbers of people with the COVID-19 infection.

Icyiciro cya III cy’igerageza kiragutse, gifite ibintu runaka kiba kigambiriye kureba mu rwego rwo kugena ingaruka n’ ubushobi n’umuti, igerageza rigakorerwa ku mubare uhagije w’abantu bafite ubwandu bwa COVID-19.
If safety and efficacy are adequately proved, clinical testing may stop at this step and the NCE advances to the new drug application (NDA) stage to begin marketing.

Iyo bigaragaye ko umuti ufite ubushobozi kandi wizewe, igerageza ry’umuti rishobora guhagarikwa kuri uru rwego hanyuma NCE igakurikizaho ikiciro gishya cyo gukoresha umuti (NDA) mu rwego rwo gutangira kuwugeza ku isoko.
Phase IV trials are post-approval trials that may be a condition attached by the FDA, also called post-market surveillance studies.
Ikiciro cya IV kiza nyuma y’igeragezwa rya nyuma yo kwemeza umuti aho FDA ishobora gushyiraho ibisabwa, bizwi ku izina rya’inyigo ku bugenzuzi bwa nyuma yo gushyira umuti ku isoko.

In addition to the tests required to move a novel vaccine or antiviral drug into the clinic for the first time, manufacturers must ensure that any long-term or chronic toxicities are well-defined, including effects on systems not previously monitored (fertility, reproduction, immune system, among others).

Uretse umubare w’igerageza usabwa kugira ngo urukingo rushya cyangwa umuti uvura virusi bijyanwe mu ivuriro kugira ngo utangire gukoreshwa, abafite inganda rikora imiti nib nta ngaruka z’igihe kirekire cyangwa karande zishobora kubaho, harimo nk’ingaruka ushibora kugira mu mikorere y’umubiri w’umuntu ( uburumbuke, kubyara, ubwirinzi bw’umubiri, n’ibindi).
In the United States, this process is called a "new drug application" or NDA.
Muri Leta Zunze Ubumwe z’Amerika, ubu buryo bwitwa “ Ikoreshwa ry’umuti mushya” cyangwa NDA mu mpine y’icyongereza.
A clinical trial design in progress may be modified as an "adaptive design" if accumulating data in the trial provide early insights about positive or negative efficacy of the treatment.

Uburyo igeragezwa ry’umuti ririmo gukorwa bushobora guhinduka “bugashingira ku bihari” mu gihe amakuru yavuye mu igerageza agaragaza ibindi bintu bishya byiza cyangwa bibi bijyanye n’ubushobozi bw’uwo muti mu kuvura.

The global Solidarity and European Discovery trials of hospitalized people with severe COVID-19 infection apply adaptive design to rapidly alter trial parameters as results from the four experimental therapeutic strategies emerge.

There are three ongoing clinical trials of intravenous vitamin C for people who are hospitalized and severely ill with COVID-19; two placebo controlled (China, Canada) and one with no control (Italy).

uruhererekane rw‘abagore batwite 43 bo muri New York basanzwemo ubwandu bwa COVID-19 rwagaraje ko ntacyo bagaragaza gitandukanye n’abandi bantu bakuze bagaragayeho ubwandu ariko badatwite: 86%bari barwaye byohroheje, 9,3% bari batangiye kumererwa nabi naho 4,7% bari indembe.
Fetal distress was reported in two.

A small study involving 6 confirmed COVID-19 mothers showed no indication of SARS-COV-19 in their newborns' throats or serum but antibodies were present in neonatal blood sera samples, including IgM in two of the infants.

A survey conducted in Shanghai among pregnant women in different trimesters of pregnancy identified a strong demand for online access to health information and services.

umuntu wahuye n’ukekwaho cyangwa byemejwe ko afite ubwandu;

COVID-19 yagaragaye mu kwezi k’Ukuboza 2019.
A major outbreak spread around the world in 2020, leading to considerable investment and research activity to develop a vaccine.
Yatangiye gusakara ku isi hose mu w‘2020, bituma hashorwa amafaranga menshi, hanatangira ibikorwa by’ubushakashatsi mu rwego rwo gushakisha urukingo.
Many organizations are using published genomes to develop possible vaccines against SARS-CoV-2.
Ibyinshi mu bigo birimo kwifashisha imiti yari isanzwe ihari mu gukora urukingo rushobora guhangana na SARS-CoV-2.
Stated in April, imperatives of the CEPI initiative for vaccine development are speed, manufacturing capacity, deployment at scale, and global access.
Guhera muri Mata, ibyo CEPI yibandaho cyane mu gushaka urukingo ni umuvuduko, ubushobozi bwo kurukora, gushaka abakozi, no kurugeza hose ku isi.
In April, CEPI scientists reported that 10 different technology platforms were under research and development during early 2020 to create an effective vaccine against COVID-19.

Muri Mata, inzobere za CEPI zatangaje ko hari uburyo 10 butandukanye bw’ikoranabuhanga burimo gukorerwaho ubushakashatsi no gukorwa mu ntangiriro za 2020 mu rwego rwo gukora urukingo rufite ubushobozi bwo guhangana na COVID-19.
Major platform targets advanced into Phase I safety studies include:
Mu buryo burimo gukorwaho bukiri mu cyiciro cya I cy’ubushakashatsi burimo:
nucleic acid (DNA and RNA) (Phase I developer and vaccine candidate: Moderna, mRNA-1273)
Uturemangingo two mu maraso (DNA na RNA) turi mu cyiciro I cy’ubushakashatsi ku rukingo ni: Moderna, mRNA-1273)
viral vector (Phase I developer and vaccine candidate: CanSino Biologics, adenovirus type 5 vector)
Uturemangingo two muri virusi (cyiciro I cy’ubushakashatsi ku rukingo: CanSino Biologics, adenovirus type 5 vector)

As reported by CEPI scientists in April, 115 total vaccine candidates are in early stages of development, with 78 confirmed as active projects (79, according to the Milken Institute), and 37 others announced, but with little public information available (presumed to be in planning or being designed).

Nkuko bitangazwa na n’inzobere za CEPI muri Mata, ubushakashatsi ku rukingo bugera kuri 115 nibwo bugitangira, harimo 78 byemejwe ko imishinga yabwo yatangiye (79, nkuko bitangazwa n’ikigo cya Milken), n’ubundi 37 bwatangajwe, ariko amakuru yabwo akaba ataramenyekana neza (bikekwa ko hari gahunda yabyo cyangwa burimo gutunganywa).
A Phase I-II trial conducts preliminary safety and immunogenicity testing, is typically randomized, placebo-controlled, and at multiple sites, while determining more precise, effective doses.

Igerageza ryo mu kiciro cya I-II ripima ubuziranenge n’ubushobozi, rikorwa muri rusange, rigakurikiranirwa hafi, rigakorerwa ahantu henshi, mu gihe haba hirindwa kwibeshya, no gushaka ingano ishobora gukoreshwa.

Phase III trials typically involve more participants, including a control group, and test effectiveness of the vaccine to prevent the disease, while monitoring for adverse effects at the optimal dose.

Ikiciro cya III k’igerageza gisaba abantu benshi, harimo itsinda rishinzwe igenzura, no gupima ubushobozi bw’urukingo mu kurinda indwara, mu gihe harimo gusuzumwa ko izindi ngaruka zaterwa n’urukingo zagabanywa zikagera ku kigero cyo kwihanganirwa.
Of 79 vaccine candidates in active development (confirmed as of early April 2020), 74 were not yet in human evaluation (still in "preclinical" research).
Mu nkingo 79 zirimo gukorwaho ( byemejwe mu ntangiriro za Mata 2020), 74 ntizari zagatangiye kugeragerezwa ku bantu (ziracyari mu bushakashatsi bw‘“ibanze).

Around 24 January 2020 in Australia, the University of Queensland announced that it is investigating the potential of a molecular clamp vaccine that would genetically modify viral proteins in order to stimulate an immune reaction.

Ahagana tariki ya 24 Mutarama 2020 muri Australia, Kaminuza ya Quensland yatangaje ko ari ubushakashatsi ku kurukingo rushobora guhindura imiterere y’uturemangingo twa virusi mu rwego rwo gufasha umubiri gukora ubwirinzi.

Around 24 January 2020 in Canada, the International Vaccine Centre (VIDO-InterVac) at the University of Saskatchewan announced the commencement of work on a vaccine, aiming to start human testing in 2021.

Ahagana tariki ya 24 Mutarama 2020 muri Canada, Ikigo mpuzamahanga gishinzwe inkingo (VIDO-InterVac) muri Kaminuza ya Saskatchewan yatangaje ko imirimo yo gukora urukingo yatangiye, ko ruzatangira kugeragerezwa ku bantu mu mwaka wa 2021.
Vaccine development projects were announced at the Chinese Center for Disease Control and Prevention on 26 January 2020, and the University of Hong Kong on 28 January.
Kuwa 26 Mutarama 2020 mu Kigo cyo mu Bushinwa gishinzwe gukurikirana no kwirinda indwara hatangajwe imishinga ku ikorwa ry’urukingo, naho muri Kaminuza ya Hong Kong itangazwa kuwa 28 Mutarama.
Around 29 January 2020, Janssen Pharmaceutical Companies, led by Hanneke Schuitemaker, announced that it had begun work on developing a vaccine.
Ahagana tariki ya 29 Mutarama 2020, Kompanyi zishinzwe imiti ziyobowe na Hanneke Schuitemaker, zatangaje ko zatangiye ibikorwa byo gukora urukingo.
Janssen is co-developing an oral vaccine with its biotechnology partner, Vaxart.
Janssen kandi, ifatanyije n’umufatanyabikorwa wayo Vaxart, irimo gukora urukingo rwajya rutangwa runyujijwe mu kanwa.
On 18 March 2020, Emergent BioSolutions announced a manufacturing partnership with Vaxart to develop the vaccine.
Kuwa 18 Gashyantare 2020, Emergent BioSolutions yatangaje ubufatanyabikorwa mu by’inganda na Vaxart mu gukora urukingo.
On 8 February 2020, the laboratory OncoGen in Romania published a paper on the design of a vaccine with similar technology to the one used for cancer neoantigen vaccination therapy.
Kuwa 8 Gashyantare 2020, laboratwari OncoGen muri Romania yasohoye ubushakashatsi ku miterere y’urukingo rufite ikoranabuhanga risa n’iry’uruvura kanseri.
On 25 March the head of the research institute announced that they had finalized the synthesis of the vaccine and were beginning the tests.
Kuwa 25 Werurwe uhagarariye ikigo cy’ubushakashatsi yatangaje ko yarangije iby’ingenzi ku rukingo, ikaba yari igiye gutangira kurugerageza.
On 27 February 2020, a Generex subsidiary company, NuGenerex Immuno-Oncology, announced they were beginning a vaccine project to create an Ii-Key peptide vaccine against COVID-19.

Kuwa 27 Gashyantare 2020, ikigo gishamikiye kuri kompanyi ya Generex, NuGenerex Immuno-Oncology, cyatangaje ko cyari kigiye gutangira umushinga wo gukora urukingo mu rwego rwo kubona urukingo rushingiye ku turemangingo dushobora guhanga na COVID-19.
They wanted to produce a vaccine candidate that could be tested in humans "within 90 days."
Bari bagamije gukora urukingo rushobora kugeragerezwa ku bantu „mu gihe cy’iminsi 90“
On 5 March 2020, Washington University in St. Louis announced its projects to develop a vaccine.
Kuwa 25 Werurwe 2020, Kaminuza ya Washington muri St. Louis yatangaje imishinga yabo mu gukora urukingo.

On 5 March 2020, the United States Army Medical Research and Materiel Command at Fort Detrick and the Walter Reed Army Institute of Research in Silver Spring, both in western Maryland, announced they were working on a vaccine.

Kuwa 5 Werurwe 2020,Ikigo cya gisirikari cyo muri Leta Zunze ubumwe z’Amerika gishinzwe ubushakashatsi ku buzima n’ibikoresho bya gisirikari i Fort Detrick n’Ishuri rikuru rya gisirikare cya Walter Reed gishinzwe ubushakashatsi ku byuma, byombi biherereye mu burengerazuba bwa Maryland, byatangaje ko birimo gukora ku rukingo.
Around 10 March 2020, Emergent Biosolutions announced that it had teamed with Novavax Inc.
Ahagana tariki ya 10 Werurwe 2020, Emergent Biosolutions yatangaje ko yatangiye imikoranire na Novavax Inc.
in the development and manufacture of a vaccine.
mu bikorwa byo gukora urukingo.
The partners further announced plans for preclinical testing and a Phase I clinical trial by July 2020.
Abafatanyabikorwa batangaje kandi ko bafite gahunda zo gupima urukingo no gutangira igerageza ryawo ku rwego rwo mu kiciro cya I bitarenze Nyakanga 2020.
On 12 March 2020, India's Health Ministry announced they are working with 11 isolates, and that even on a fast track it would take at least around one-and-a-half to two years to develop a vaccine.

Kuwa 5 Werurwe 2020, Minisiteri y’ubuzima mu Buhinde yatangaje ko irimo gukora miti 11 kandi ko ku ikubitiro bizatwara nibura hagati y’umwaka umwe n’umwaka n’igice n’imyaka ibiri kugira ngo urukingo rukorwe.
On 12 March 2020, Medicago, a biotechnology company in Quebec City, Quebec, reported development of a coronavirus-like particle under partial funding from the Canadian Institutes for Health Research.

Kuwa 5 Werurwe 2020,Medicago, kompanyi y’ubuzima yo mu mugi wa Quebec muri Quebec, yatangaje ikorwa ry’umuti ushobora guhangana na koronavirusi ibitewemo inkunga n’Ikigo cy’ubushakashatsi mu by’ubuzima cyo muri Canada.
The vaccine candidate is in laboratory research, with human testing planned for July or August 2020.
Urukingo ruracyakorwaho ushakashatsi muri laboratwari, rukaba ruteganya kurugeregereza ku bantu muri Nyakanga cyangwa Kanama 2020.

Earlier that week, The Guardian reported that the US President Donald Trump had offered CureVac "'large sums of money' for exclusive access to a Covid-19 vaccine", against which the German government protested.

Mbere gato muri icyo cyumweru, The Guardian yatangaje ko Perezida wa Leta Zunze ubumwe z’Amerika Donald Trump yatanze “amafaranga menshi agenewe gusa ibikorwa byo kubona urukingo rwa Covid-19 ikintu cyamaganiwe kure guverinoma y’Ubudage.
On 17 March 2020, American pharmaceutical company Pfizer announced a partnership with German company BioNTech to jointly develop a mRNA-based vaccine.
Kuwa 5 Werurwe 2020, Kompanyi y’imiti yitwa Pfizer yatangaje ubufatanye na kompanyi y’Abadage yitwa BioNTech mu rwego rwo gukora urukingo rushingiye ku turemangingo twa mRNA .
mRNA-based vaccine candidate BNT162, currently in pre-clinical testing with clinical trials expected to begin in April 2020.
Urukingo rushingiye ku turemangingo twa mRNA rufite izina rya BNT162, kugeza ubu rukiri gupimwa kandi igeragezwa ryarwo rirateganya gutangira muri Mata 2020.

In Italy on 17 March 2020, Takis Biotech, an Italian biotech company announced they will have pre-clinical testing results in April 2020 and their final vaccine candidate could begin human testing by fall.

Kuwa 17 Werurwe 2020, mu Butariyani, Kompanyi y’ubuzima yitwa Takis Biotech, yatangaje ko izabona ibisubizo by’ibipimo byafashwe muri Mata 2020 hanyuma urukingo rukazahita rutangira kugeragerezwa ku bantu.

In France on 19 March 2020, the Coalition for Epidemic Preparedness Innovations (CEPI) announced a US$4.9 million investment in a COVID-19 vaccine research consortium involving the Institut Pasteur, Themis Bioscience (Vienna, Austria), and the University of Pittsburgh, bringing CEPI's total investment in COVID-19 vaccine development to US$29 million.

Kuwa 19 Werurwe 2020 mu Bufaransa, Ihuriro rya gahunda yo kurwanya ibiza (CEPI) ryatangaje ko hashowe miliyoni US$4.9 mu bushakashatsi ku rukingo rw COVID-19 burimo gukorwa na Institut Pasteur, Themis Bioscience (Vienna, Austria), na Kaminuza ya Pittsburgh, bituma umubare w’amafaranga CEPI imaze gushora mu gushaka urukingo rwa COVID-19 ugera kuri miliyoni US$29.
CEPI's other investment partners for COVID-19 vaccine development are Moderna, Curevac, Inovio, Novavax, the University of Hong Kong, the University of Oxford, and the University of Queensland.
Abandi bafatanyabikorwa ba CEPI bashoye imari mu gukora urukingo rwa COVID-19 ni Moderna, Curevac, Inovio, Novavax, Kaminuza ya Hong Kong, Kaminuza ya Oxford, na Kaminuza ya Queensland.
On 20 March 2020, Russian health officials announced that scientists have begun animal testing of six different vaccine candidates.
Kuwa Werurwe 2020, abayobozi b’inzego z’ubuzima mu Burusiya batangaje ko inzobere zatangiye gupima inyamaswa zakoreweho igeragezwa ry’inkingo esheshstu.
Imperial College London researchers announced on 20 March 2020 that they are developing a self-amplifying RNA vaccine for COVID-19.
Abashakashatsi muri Imperial College London batangaje kuwa 20 Werurwe 2020 ko barimo gukora urukingo rwa COVID-19 rushingiye ku turemangingo two mu maraso .
The vaccine candidate was developed within 14 days of receiving the sequence from China.
Urukingo rwakozwe mu minsi 14 nyuma yo gushyikirizwa n’igihugu cy‘Ubushinwa ibikenerwa.

In late March, the Canadian government announced C$275 million in funding for 96 research projects on medical countermeasures against COVID-19, including numerous vaccine candidates at Canadian companies and universities, such as the Medicago and University of Saskatchewan initiatives.

Mu mpera za Werurwe, guverinoma ya Canada yatangaje miliyoni C$275 yo gutera inkunga imishinga 96 ku ngamba zo guhangana na COVID-19, harimo ikora ku nkingo zitandukanye mu bigo na za kaminuza zo muri Canada, nk’izirimo gukorwa na Medicago na Kaminuza ya Saskatchewan.

Around the same time, the Canadian government announced C$192 million specifically for developing a COVID-19 vaccine, with plans to establish a national "vaccine bank" of several new vaccines that could be used if another coronavirus outbreak occurs.

Ahagana muri cyo gihe, guverinoma ya Canada yatangaje ko hari miliyoni C$192 zagenewe gusa gukora urukingo rwa COVID-19 , hagamijwe gushyiraho “ububiko bw’urukingo” bubitse inkingo nyinshi zishobora kwifashishwa igihe haba hadutse ikindi cyorezo cya koronavirusi .

On 2 April 2020, researchers at the University of Pittsburgh School of Medicine reported on testing of PittCoVacc, a possible COVID-19 vaccine in mice, stating that "MNA delivered SARS-CoV-2 S1 subunit vaccines elicited potent antigen-specific antibody responses [in the mice] that were evident beginning 2 weeks after immunization."

Kuwa 2 Mata 2020, abashakashatsi bo ku Ishuri ry’ubuvuzi ryo muri Kaminuza ya Pittsburgh batangaje ko barimo kugeragereza mu mbeba urukingo rwa PittCoVacc, rushobora kuvamo urukingo rwa COVID-19, batangaza ko “uduce tw’urukingo rwa SARS-CoV-2 S1 duturuka mu turemangingo dutangwa na MNA twagaragaje ubushobozi bwo gukora abasirikari barinda umubiri [mu mbeba], bikaba byaratangiye kugaragara guhera mu ntangiriro z’ibyumweru 2 nyuma yo kurukoresha."
In Canada on 16 April 2020, the University of Waterloo School of Pharmacy announced design of a DNA-based vaccine candidate as a possible nasal spray.
Kuwa 16 Mata 2020, mu ishuri ryigisha iby’imiti ryo muri Kaminuza ya Waterloo batangaje ko barimo gukora urukingo rushingiye kuri DNA rushobora kuzajya runyuzwa mu mazuru.

Using bacteriophages, the DNA will be designed to replicate inside human bacteria to produce harmless virus-like particles, which may stimulate the immune system to produce antibodies against the SARS-CoV-2 virus.

Hakoreshejwe virusi yica udukoko, DNA izakorwa ku buryo yinjizwa mu gakoko kugira ngo ibyare uduce dusa na virusi idatera ibibazo, utu tukazatuma ubwirinzi bw’umubiri bukanguka bugatuma hakorwa abasirikari b’umubiri bo kurwanya virusi ya SARS-CoV-2 .

In March 2020, the US government, industry, and three universities pooled resources to access supercomputers from IBM, combined with cloud computing resources from Hewlett Packard Enterprise, Amazon, Microsoft, and Google.

Muri Werurwe 2020, guverinoma ya Leta Zunze Ubumwe z’Amerika, uruganda, na kaminuza eshatu bakusanyije amakuru agamije kubona za mudasobwa kabuhariwe za IBM, hamwe n’ibindi bintu by’ikoranabuhanga rya mudasobwa rya Hewlett Packard Enterprise, Amazon, Microsoft, na Google.
Some vaccines have heterologous effects, also called non-specific effects.
Inkingo zimwe zifite ingaruka z’ubwoko butandukanye, zikunze kwitwa ingaruka zitazwi.
That means they can have benefits beyond the disease they prevent.
Ibi bivuze ko zishobora kugira ingaruka nziza ziyongera ku ndwara zirinda.
A further randomized trial in Australia is seeking to enrol 4,170 healthcare workers.
Irindi gerageza ryo muri Australia rimo gushaka abaganga 4,170 bo kwifashisha.
It is possible vaccines in development will not be safe or effective.
Birashoboka ko inkingo zirimo gukorwa zizaba zidafite ubuziranenge cyangwa zikaba nta bushobozi zifite.

Early research to assess vaccine efficacy using COVID-19-specific animal models, such as ACE2-transgenic mice, other laboratory animals, and non-human primates, indicate a need for biosafety-level 3 containment measures for handling live viruses, and international coordination to ensure standardized safety procedures.

Ubushakashatsi bwa vuba bwo gusuzuma ubushobozi bw’urukingo hakoreshejwe inyamashwa zatoranyijwe za COVID-19, nk’imbeba zo mu bwoko bwa ACE2 n’inguge, zigaragaza ko hakenewe ingamba zijyanye no kubungabunga ubuziranenge bwo mu rwego rwa 3, mu rwego rwo guhangana na virusi ihari, n’ubufatanye bwo ku rwego mpuzamahanga hagamijwe kubahiriza amabwiriza ajyanye n’ubuziranenge.
Vaccines against SARS and MERS have been tested in non-human animal models.
Inkingo zo kurwanya SARS na MERS zageragerejwe ku nyamaswa.
As of 2020, there is no cure or protective vaccine for SARS that has been shown to be both safe and effective in humans.
kugeza ubu muri 2020,nta muti cyangwa urukingo bya SARS na MERS byari byagaragara ko bifite ubuziranenge n’ubushobozi mu mubiri w’umuntu .

According to research papers published in 2005 and 2006, the identification and development of novel vaccines and medicines to treat SARS was a priority for governments and public health agencies around the world.There is also no proven vaccine against MERS.

Nkuko byatangajwe n’ubushakashatsi bwo mu myaka ya 2005 na 2006, kuvumbura no gukora inkingo n’imiti bya SARS byari ibintu byihutirwa muri gahunda ya leta n’ibigo by’ubuzima ku isi hose. Nta n’urukingo rwa MERS rwari rwemezwa.
When MERS became prevalent, it was believed that existing SARS research may provide a useful template for developing vaccines and therapeutics against a MERS-CoV infection.
Igihe MERS yari yasakaye, hari hitezwe ko ubushakashatsi bwarimo gukorwa bwashoboraga ugutanga buryo bufatika bwo gukora inkingo n’imiti byo kwirinda ubwandu bwa MERS-CoV.

As of March 2020, there was one (DNA based) MERS vaccine which completed phase I clinical trials in humans, and three others in progress, all of which are viral-vectored vaccines, two adenoviral-vectored (ChAdOx1-MERS, BVRS-GamVac), and one MVA-vectored (MVA-MERS-S).

Kugera muri Werurwe 2020, hari urukingo rwa MERS (rushingiye kuri DNA) rwari rumaze kurangiza ikiciro cya I k’igeragezwa rikorewe ku bantu, n’izindi eshatu zari zigikorwaho, izo zose akaba ari izitangwa mu buryo bwa virusi, ebyiri zo mu bwoko bwa virusi yitwa “Adenoviridae” (ChAdOx1-MERS, BVRS-GamVac), na rumwe rwo mu bwoko bwa MVA (MVA-MERS-S).
Social media posts have promoted a conspiracy theory claiming the virus behind COVID-19 was known and that a vaccine was already available.
Imbuga nkoranyambaga zakwirakwije ibihuha bivuga ko COVID-19 yari isanzwe izwi kandi ko n’urukingo rwayo rwari rusanzwe ruhari.
The patents cited by various social media posts reference existing patents for genetic sequences and vaccines for other strains of coronavirus such as the SARS coronavirus.
Ibyibanzweho n’imbuga nkoranyambaga ni ibijyanye no kuba hasanzwe hariho uturemangingo n’inkingo by’ibindi bibazo bya koronavirusi nka koronavirusi yo mu bwoko bwa SARS.
b'Coronaviruses are a group of related viruses that cause diseases in mammals and birds.
Virusi yo mu bwoko bwa korona b’ ni itsinda rya za virusi ziterwa n’indwara zituruka ku nyamabere n’inyoni.
In humans, coronaviruses cause respiratory tract infections that can range from mild to lethal.
Mu bantu , koronavirusi itera uburwayi bwo mu bice by’ubuhumekero bishobora kuba byoroshye cyangwa bifite ubukana bwinshi.
Mild illnesses include some cases of the common cold (which has other possible causes, predominantly rhinoviruses), while more lethal varieties can cause SARS, MERS, and COVID-19.

Indwara zoroheje zirimo zimwe z’ibicurane (bishobora guterwa n’izindi mpamvu, cyane kurushaho virusi ziterwa n’inkura / rinovirusi) mu gihe izifite ubukana bwinshi zishobora gutera SARS, MERS, na COVID-19.
Symptoms in other species vary: in chickens, they cause an upper respiratory tract disease, while in cows and pigs they cause diarrhea.
Ibimenyetso mu bindi binyabuzima birahinduka: ku nkoko, zitera ibibazo bikomeye byo guhumeka, mu gihe ku nka n’ingurube zitera impiswi.
There are yet to be vaccines or antiviral drugs to prevent or treat human coronavirus infections.
Haracyakenewe rero inkingo cyangwa imiti byo kwirinda cyangwa kuvura ubwandu bwa koronavirusi ku bantu.
Coronaviruses constitute the subfamily Orthocoronavirinae, in the family Coronaviridae, order Nidovirales, and realm Riboviria.
Koronavirusi iri mu muryango wa Orthocoronavirinae, mu muryango wa Coronaviridae, order Nidovirales, na realm Riboviria.
They are enveloped viruses with a positive-sense single-stranded RNA genome and a nucleocapsid of helical symmetry.
Ni virusi zifunze mu turemangingo twa RNA hamwe n’ibyo bita nucleocapsid.
The genome size of coronaviruses ranges from approximately 26 to 32 kilobases, one of the largest among RNA viruses.
Ingano y’akaremangingo ka za koronavirusi ibarirwa hagati ya kilobaze 26 na 32, ikaba ari zimwe muri virusi za RNA.
They have characteristic club-shaped spikes that project from their surface, which in electron micrographs create an image reminiscent of the solar corona from which their name derives.
Zirangwa n’uduhembe tw’ibinure turi hejuru yazo , aho utuce twazo tukora ishusho ya korona yo ku zuba akaba ari naho izina ryazo rituruka.
Coronaviruses were first discovered in the 1930s when an acute respiratory infection of domesticated chickens was shown to be caused by infectious bronchitis virus (IBV).
Virusi za korona zavumbuwe bwa mbere mu myaka yo mu 1930, ubwo hari hamaze kugaragazwa ko ubwandu bukomeye bwo mu buhumekero ku nkoko buterwa na virusi itera udusebe mu myanya y’ubuhumekero (IBV).
In the 1940s, two more animal coronaviruses, mouse hepatitis virus (MHV) and transmissible gastroenteritis virus (TGEV), were isolated.Human coronaviruses were discovered in the 1960s.

Mu myaka ya za 1940, hagaragaye izindi ndwra ebyiri za koronavirusi yo mu nyanaswa, iyo mu bwoko bwataka impyiko z’imbeba (MHV) na virusi yandurira muri gazi yo mu gifu (TGEV). Koronavirusi yo mu bantu yagaragaye muri za 1960.
The earliest ones studied were from human patients with the common cold, which were later named human coronavirus 229E and human coronavirus OC43.
iziheruka gukorwaho ubushakashatsi zari izisanzwe mu barwayi bafite ikibazo k’ibicurane, zahise zitwa koronavirusi zifata abantu zo mu bwoko bwa 229E na koronavirusi zo mu bantu zitwa OC43.
They were first imaged by Scottish virologist June Almeida at St. Thomas Hospital in London.
Zagaragajwe bwa mbere n’umuganga wize ibijyanye na virusi wo muri Sikotilandi muri Kamena ahitwa Almeida mu bitaro byitiriwe Mutagatifu Thomas l byo muri London.
Other human coronaviruses have since been identified, including SARS-CoV in 2003, HCoV NL63 in 2004, HKU1 in 2005, MERS-CoV in 2012, and SARS-CoV-2 in 2019.
Guhera icyo gihe havumbuwe izindi koronavirusi, zirimo SARS-CoV muri 2003, HCoV NL63 muri 2004, HKU1 muri 2005, MERS-CoV muri 2012, na SARS-CoV-2 muri 2019.
Most of these have involved serious respiratory tract infections.
Inyinshi muri izi zitera indwara zikomeye z’ubuhumero.
The name was first used in 1968 by an informal group of virologists in the journal Nature to designate the new family of viruses.
Izina ryakoreshejwe bwa mbere mu mwaka wa 1968, rikoreshejwe n’itsinda ritazwi ry’abaganga b’indwara ziterwa na virusi mu kinyamakuru kitwa Nature bashaka kuvuga ubwoko bushya bwa virusi.

The name refers to the characteristic appearance of virions (the infective form of the virus) by electron microscopy, which have a fringe of large, bulbous surface projections creating an image reminiscent of a crown or of a solar corona.

Izina risobanura ibiranga virusi bigaragarira amaso (agace gafite ubushobozi bwo kwanduza virusi) biboneka hakoreshejwe mikorosikopi, ifite impande zagutse, ifite isura y’uruziga bituma igaragara nk’ifoto y’izuba .
This morphology is created by the viral spike peplomers, which are proteins on the surface of the virus.
Iyi sura igaragazwa n’amahembe, akaba ari intungabuzima ziba ziri inyuma kuri virusi.
Coronaviruses are large pleomorphic spherical particles with bulbous surface projections.
Za koranavirusi ni utubumbe tunini dufite amahembe.

The envelope of the virus in electron micrographs appears as a distinct pair of electron dense shells.The viral envelope consists of a lipid bilayer where the membrane (M), envelope (E) and spike (S) structural proteins are anchored.

ishusho ya Virusi nshya muri mikorosikopi igaragara nk’uduce duto twishyize hamwe. Virusi igizwe n’ikinure cy’imirasire ibiri aho intungabuzima z’igice k’inyuma (M), igice gikurikira igice k’inyuma(E)n’igisamahembe (S) ahaba hari intungamubiri.
The lipid bilayer envelope, membrane proteins, and nucleocapsid protect the virus when it is outside the host cell.
Ikinure cy’imirasire ibiri, intungabuzima z’igice k’inyuma hamwe n’ik’imbere birinda virusi iyo isohotse mu kinyabuzima cyayanduye .
Coronaviruses contain a positive-sense, single-stranded RNA genome.
Koronavirusi ifite uturemangingo twa RNA dufite ubuzima kandi tugiye umujyo umwe.
The genome size for coronaviruses ranges from 26.4 to 31.7 kilobases.
Ingano y’uturemangingo twa koronavirusi iri hagati ya kilobaze 26.4 na 31.7.
The genome size is one of the largest among RNA viruses.
Iyi niyo virusi ifite uturemangingo tunini ugereranyije n’izindi zo mu bwoko bwa RNA.
The open reading frames 1a and 1b, which occupy the first two-thirds of the genome, encode the replicase/transcriptase polyprotein.
Ibice bya mbere 1a na 1b , bikaba bifata umwanya ungana na bibiri bya gatatu bya virusi yose, bituma habaho iyororoka/ ikura ry’intungabuzima zitandukanye za virusi.
The replicase/transcriptase polyprotein self cleaves to form nonstructural proteins.The later reading frames encode the four major structural proteins: spike, envelope, membrane, and nucleocapsid.

Iyororoka/ ikura ry’intungabuzima zitandukanye ryikora kugira ngo habeho imiterere y’intungabuzima. Ibishashi bya nyuma bigizwe n’ibice bine by’ingenzi by’intungabuzima: Ihembe, igice k’inyuma,uruhu n’igice k’imbere.
Interspersed between these reading frames are the reading frames for the accessory proteins.
Ihuzwa ry’ibi bice rikorwa mu buryo butuma byose bishobora kubona uko zihura.
The number of accessory proteins and their function is unique depending on the specific coronavirus.
Umubare w’uduce duhuza ibyo bice n’akamaro katwo urihariye bitewe na koronavirusi runaka.
Infection begins when the viral spike (S) glycoprotein attaches to its complementary host cell receptor.
Ubwandu butangira kubaho iyo ihembe rya virusi (S) rihuye n’akaremangingo k’umubiri w’uwakira virusi .
After attachment, a protease of the host cell cleaves and activates the receptor-attached spike protein.
Nyuma yo guhura, akaremangingo k’uwakiriye virusi kicamo ibice hanyuma kagatuma habaho ikindi gice gishya gifite amahembe mu mubiri .

Depending on the host cell protease available, cleavage and activation allows the virus to enter the host cell by endocytosis or direct fusion of the viral envelop with the host membrane.On entry into the host cell, the virus particle is uncoated, and its genome enters the cell cytoplasm.

Bitewe n’uturemangingo turi mu mubiri w’ikinyabuzima cyakira, ishwanyagurika n’itangira ryo gukorwa kwa virusi bituma virusi yinjira mu mubiri ishongera cyangwa ihita yinjira mu mubiri w’uyanduye. Ikimara kwinjira mu mubiri, virusi iba idatwikirye kandi uturemangingo twayo twinjira mu kinyabuzima.
The host ribosome translates the initial overlapping open reading frame of the virus genome and forms a long polyprotein.
Akaremangingo kakiriye virusi gahindura imiterere yayo kakayihinduramo ikinure kirekire.
The polyprotein has its own proteases which cleave the polyprotein into multiple nonstructural proteins.
Icyo kinure gifite uturemangingo twacyo bwite dushwanyaguza icyo kinure kikavamo uturemangingo dutandukanye.
A number of the nonstructural proteins coalesce to form a multi-protein replicase-transcriptase complex (RTC).
Umubare w’uturemangingo dutandukanye turiyegeranya tugakora ikintu kimwe gishobora kororoka no gukura (RTC).
The main replicase-transcriptase protein is the RNA-dependent RNA polymerase (RdRp).
Ikinyabuzima gishobora kororoka no gukura gishingiye kuri RNA igizwe n’uturemangingo twayo dutandukanye (RdRp).
It is directly involved in the replication and transcription of RNA from an RNA strand.
Ihita ako kanya yinjira mu iyororoka n’ikura rya RNA yavuye mu ishwanyuka rya RNA.
The other nonstructural proteins in the complex assist in the replication and transcription process.
Utundi turemangingo dutandukanye tugira uruhare mu iyororoka n’ikura .

The exoribonuclease nonstructural protein, for instance, provides extra fidelity to replication by providing a proofreading function which the RNA-dependent RNA polymerase lacks.One of the main functions of the complex is to replicate the viral genome.
Uturemangingo tw’inyuma, urugero, two dukurikirana igikorwa cy’iyororoka tukareba icyo uturemangingo twa RNA twaba tubura. Akamaro katwo k’ibanze ni korora uturemangingo twa virusi.
RdRp directly mediates the synthesis of negative-sense genomic RNA from the positive-sense genomic RNA.
RdRp ihuza ako kanya uturemangingo duteye nabi n’uduteye neza.
This is followed by the replication of positive-sense genomic RNA from the negative-sense genomic RNA.
Ibi bikurikirwa n’iyororka ry’uturemangingo twa RNA duteye neza twari duyeye nabi mbere.
The other important function of the complex is to transcribe the viral genome.
Akandi kamaro k’ingenzi k’iryo tsinda ni uguhindagura akaremangingo ka virusi.
RdRp directly mediates the synthesis of negative-sense subgenomic RNA molecules from the positive-sense genomic RNA.
RdRp ihuza ako kanya uduce tw’uturemangingo duteye nabi twavuye uduteye neza.
This is followed by the transcription of these negative-sense subgenomic RNA molecules to their corresponding positive-sense mRNAs.
Ibi bikurikirwa n’ihindagurika ry’utu duce tw’uturemangingo twa RNA duteye nabi tugahuzwa n’uduteye neza twa mRNAs.
The replicated positive-sense genomic RNA becomes the genome of the progeny viruses.
Uturemangingo twaturutse mu iyororoka duhinduka tumwe mu tugize virusi.
The mRNAs are gene transcripts of the last third of the virus genome after the initial overlapping reading frame.
uturemangingo twa mRNAs ni udutce tw’utunyangingo tugize icya gatatu k’ikinure cya virusi cya mbere.
These mRNAs are translated by the host's ribosomes into the structural proteins and a number of accessory proteins.
Utu turemangingo twa mRNA duhindurirwa imiterere n’ikinyabuzima cyatwakiriye tugahita natwo dukora ikinyabuzima cyatwo kigizwe n’uturemangingo dutandukanye.
RNA translation occurs inside the endoplasmic reticulum.
Ihinduka rya RNA ribera mu gice k’imbere k’ikinyabuzima.
The viral structural proteins S, E, and M move along the secretory pathway into the Golgi intermediate compartment.
uduce tugize virusi aritwo S, E na M tugendana n’ururenda rwatwo rugakora inzira mucyo bita Golgi.
There, the M proteins direct most protein-protein interactions required for assembly of viruses following its binding to the nucleocapsid.
Aha, uduce tugize M tuyobora uduce ku tundi duce dukenewe na virusi bitewe n’imiterere y’igice k’imbere.
Progeny viruses are then released from the host cell by exocytosis through secretory vesicles.
Uduce tugize virusi duhita noneho turekurwa tugasohoka mu kinyabuzima cyatwakiriye twifashishije ururenda.
The interaction of the coronavirus spike protein with its complement host cell receptor is central in determining the tissue tropism, infectivity, and species range of the virus.
Ikorana ry’udutwe twa virusi hamwe n’akaremangingo k’ikinyabuzima cyayakiriye ni ikintu gishingirwaho mu kumenya imiterere , ubwandure, n’ibigize virusi.
The SARS coronavirus, for example, infects human cells by attaching to the angiotensin-converting enzyme 2 (ACE2) receptor.
Koronavirusi ya SARS, urugero, igera mu turengingo tugize umubiri w’umuntu tuyihuza n’icyo bita “angiotensin-converting enzyme 2 (ACE2)” mu cyongereza.
The scientific name for coronavirus is Orthocoronavirinae or Coronavirinae.
Izina rya gihanga rya Koronavirusi ni “Orthocoronavirinae” cyangwa “Coronavirinae”.
Coronaviruses belong to the family of Coronaviridae, order Nidovirales, and realm Riboviria.
Koronavirusi ziri mu muryango wa “Coronaviridae”, “order Nidovirales”, na “realm Riboviria”.
Genus Betacoronavirus; type species: Murine coronavirus
Genus Betacoronavirus; ubwoko : koronavirusi ya mu mbeba

Species: Betacoronavirus 1 (Bovine Coronavirus, Human coronavirus OC43), Human coronavirus HKU1, Murine coronavirus, Pipistrellus bat coronavirus HKU5, Rousettus bat coronavirus HKU9, Severe acute respiratory syndrome-related coronavirus (SARS-CoV, SARS-CoV-2), Tylonycteris bat coronavirus HKU4, Middle East respiratory syndrome-related coronavirus, Hedgehog coronavirus 1 (EriCoV)

Ubwoko: Betacoronavirus 1 (Coronavirus yo mu nka, coronavirus OC43 yo mu Bantu),coronavirus HKU1 yo mu bantu, coronavirus yo mu mbeba, coronavirus HKU5 yo mu ducurama two mu bwoko bwa Pipistrellus, coronavirus HKU9 yo mu ducurama two mu bwoko bwa Rousettus, Indwara ikomeye y’igikatu ya coronavirus ifata inzira y’ubuhumekero (SARS-CoV, SARS-CoV-2), coronavirus HKU4 yo mu ducurama two mu bwoko bwa Tylonycteris, Indwara iboneka mu Burasirazuba bwo Hagati ifitanye isano na coronavirus, coronavirus 1 (EriCoV) yo mu mbuni
Species: Beluga whale coronavirus SW1, Infectious bronchitis virus
Ubwoko: Beluga whale coronavirus SW1, virusi itera buronshite

The most recent common ancestor (MRCA) of all coronaviruses is estimated to have existed as recently as 8000 BCE, although some models place the common ancestor as far back as 55 million years or more, implying long term coevolution with bat and avian species.

Igisekuru (MRCA) cya nyuma cya za koronavirusi bivugwa ko kiri mu myaka 8000 mbere y’ivuka rya yezu, nubwo hari amwe mu makuru avuga ko igisekuru rusange gishyirwa mu myaka ya kera ahagana mu yaka miliyoni 55 cyangwa mbere yaho, bikavuga ko yamaraga igihe kinini mu gacurama n’ibindi biguruka.

The most recent common ancestor of the alphacoronavirus line has been placed at about 2400 BCE, the betacoronavirus line at 3300 BCE, the gammacoronavirus line at 2800 BCE, and the deltacoronavirus line at about 3000 BCE.

Igisekuru giheruka cya alphacoronavirus gishyirwa mu myaka ya za 2400 mbere y’ivuka rya Yezu, betacoronavirus muri 3300 mbere y’ivuka rya Yezu, gammacoronavirus at 2800 mbere y’ivuka rya Yezu, naho deltacoronavirus ikabarirwa mu myaka ya za 3000 mbere y’ivuka rya Yezu.
The large number of host bat and avian species, and their global range, has enabled extensive evolution and dissemination of coronaviruses.Many human coronavirus have their origin in bats.

Umubare munini w’uducurama n’ibiguruka byakira virusi, n’ ikigererenyo cyabyo ku isi, watumye koronavirusi irushaho kororoka no gukwirakwira. Koronavirusi zandurwa n’abantu inyinshi zituruka mu ducurama.
More recently, alpaca coronavirus and human coronavirus 229E diverged sometime before 1960.
Vuba aha, koronavirusi yo mu bwoko bwa alpaca na koronavirusi zandurwa n’abantu 229E zadutse mbere ya 1960.
MERS-CoV emerged in humans from bats through the intermediate host of camels.
MERS-CoV yageze mu bantu iturutse mu ducurama inyuze mu ngamiya zayanduye.
MERS-CoV, although related to several bat coronavirus species, appears to have diverged from these several centuries ago.
MERS-CoV, nubwo ifitanye n’ubwoko bwinshi bwa koronavirusi, isa nkaho yabayeho guhera mu binyejana byinshi byashize.
The most closely related bat coronavirus and SARS-CoV diverged in 1986.
Koronavirusi ifitanye isano ya hafi n’agacurama hamwe na SARS-CoV zatangiye kubaho mu mwaka w’ 1986.
A possible path of evolution, of SARS coronavirus and keen bat coronaviruses, suggests that SARS related coronaviruses coevolved in bats for a long time.
uburyo bushoboka yagiye ikuramo, bijyanye na koronavirusi ya SARS n’iyo mu ducurama, bigaragara ko Koronavirusi zifitanye isano na SARS zagiye zikurana mu ducurama igihe kirekire.
In the 1790s, equine coronavirus diverged from the bovine coronavirus after a cross-species jump.
mu myaka ya 1790, koronavirusi yo mu ndogobe yakomotse muri koronavirusi yo mu nyamaswa zo mu bwoko bw’inka nyuma yo kunyura mu binyabuzima bitandukanye.
Later in the 1890s, human coronavirus OC43 diverged from bovine coronavirus after another cross-species spillover event.
Nyuma muri za 1890, koronavirusi yo mu bantu OC43 yakomotse muri koronavirusi yo mu nyamaswa zo mu bwoko bw’inka coronavirus nyuma yo kunyura mu bindi binyabuzima bitandukanye.

It is speculated that the flu pandemic of 1890 may have been caused by this spillover event, and not by the influenza virus, because of the related timing, neurological symptoms, and unknown causative agent of the pandemic.

Bivugwa ko icyorezo k’ibicurane cyo mu w’1890 cyaba cyaraturutse ku gikorwa cyo kwanduzanya, ko atari kuri virusi itera ibicurane, bitewe n’igihe, ibimenyetso byo mu bwonko, n’igitera icyo cyorezo kitazwi.
Human coronavirus OC43 besides causing respiratory infections is also suspected of playing a role in neurological diseases.
Usibye kuba Koronavirusi yo mu bantu OC43 itera ibibazo byo mu buhumekero, bivugwa ko igira n’uruhare mu ndwara zo mu bwonko.
In the 1950s, the human coronavirus OC43 began to diverge into its present genotypes.
Muri za 1950, Koronavirusi yo mu bantu OC43 yatangiye kubaho iteye uko tuyibona ubu.
Phylogentically, mouse hepatitis virus (Murine coronavirus), which infects the mouse's liver and the central nervous system, is related to human coronavirus OC43 and bovine coronavirus.
Hashingiwe ku isano iba hagati y’ibinyabuzima, virusi yo mu mbeba, ifata umwijima n’igice cyo hagati by’imbeba, ifitanye isano na Koronavirusi yo mu bantu OC43 ndetse n’iyo mu bimasa.
Human coronavirus HKU1, like the aforementioned viruses, also has its origins in rodents.
Koronavirusi yo mu bantu HKU1, kimwe n’izindi viruse zavuzwe haruguru, ifite nayo inkomoko mu dusimba dufitanye isano n’imbeba.
Coronaviruses vary significantly in risk factor.
Koronavirusi zigenda zigira ingaru zitandukanye.
Some can kill more than 30% of those infected, such as MERS-CoV, and some are relatively harmless, such as the common cold.
Zimwe zishobora kwica 30% by’ibinyabuzima byazanduye, urugero nka MERS-CoV, izindi nazo wavuga ko ntacyo zitwaye, urugero nk’izitera kugira imbeho.
Coronaviruses can cause colds with major symptoms, such as fever, and a sore throat from swollen adenoids.
Koronavirusi zishobora gutera gutengurwa gukabije kurangwa n’ibintu bitandukanye, nk’umuriro na kubabara mu muhogo kwatewe no kubyimba k’ibice byo mu muhogo.
Coronaviruses can cause pneumonia (either direct viral pneumonia or secondary bacterial pneumonia) and bronchitis (either direct viral bronchitis or secondary bacterial bronchitis).

Koronavirusi zishobora gutera indwara zo kubura umwuka (bitewe na virusi yahise ijya mu myanya y’ubuhumekero cyangwa udukoko twahageze nyuma) ndetse n’indwara za bronshite (bitewe na virusi yahise ijyamu myanya y’ubuhumekero cyangwa udukoko twahageze nyuma).

The human coronavirus discovered in 2003, SARS-CoV, which causes severe acute respiratory syndrome (SARS), has a unique pathogenesis because it causes both upper and lower respiratory tract infections.Six species of human coronaviruses are known, with one species subdivided into two different strains, making seven strains of human coronaviruses altogether.

Koronavirusi yo mu bantu yavumbuwe mu w’ 2003, SARS-CoV, itera ibibazo bikomeye byo mu buhumekero (SARS), ifite imiterere yihariye kubera ko itera ibibazo byoroshye n’ibikomeye byo mu myanya y’ubuhumekero. Hari ubwoko butandatu buzwi bwa koronavirusi yo mu bantu, harimo bumwe bugabanyijemo utundi duce, ibi bigatuma umubare wa za koronavirusi zo mu bantu ugera kuri karindwi.
Four of these coronaviruses continually circulate in the human population and produce the generally mild symptoms of the common cold in adults and children worldwide: -OC43, -HKU1, HCoV-229E, -NL63.

Bune mu bwoko bwa koronavirusi bukomeje gukwirakwira mu bantu kandi muri rusange bugira ibimenyetso byoroshye by’ibicurane mu bantu bakuze ndetse no mu bana ku rwego rw'isi kandi izo koronavirusi ni izi zikurikira: -OC43, -HKU1, HCoV-229E, -NL63.
Coronaviruses cause about 15% of commons colds.
Koronavirusi zitera 15% z’indwara z’ibicurane.
The majority of colds are caused by rhinoviruses.
Inyinshi mu ndwara z’indwara z’ibicurane ziterwa na virusi zo mu nkura ( rhinoviruses).
The four mild coronaviruses have a seasonal incidence occurring in the winter months in temperate climates.
Koronavirusi enye zoroheje ziterwa n’ihindagurika ry’ikirere biba mu gihe cy’imvura (umuhindo) kirangwa n’ubukonje buringaniye.
There is no preference towards a particular season in tropical climates.
Nta gihe kihariye kijyanye n’ikirere izi virusi zikunze kugaragaramo.
Four human coronaviruses produce symptoms that are generally mild:
Koronavirusi zo mu bantu enye zigaragaza ibimenyetso muri rusange byoroshye :
The virus was officially named the SARS coronavirus (SARS-CoV).
Virusi yahawe izina ku mugaragaro rya koronavirusi ya SARS (SARS-CoV).
More than 8,000 people were infected, about ten percent of whom died.
Abantu barenga 8,000 bamaze kwandura, icumi ku ijana byabo baka baritabye Imana.
In September 2012, a new type of coronavirus was identified, initially called Novel Coronavirus 2012, and now officially named Middle East respiratory syndrome coronavirus (MERS-CoV).

Muri Nzeri 2012, hagaragaye ubwoko bushya bwa koronavirusi, ku ikubitiro bwiswe izina rya “Novel Coronavirus 2012”, ubu ikaba yarahawe izina rya” Middle East respiratory syndrome coronavirus (MERS-CoV)”.
The World Health Organization issued a global alert soon after.
Ishami ry’Umuryango w’Abibumbye Ryita ku Buzima ryahise riburira isi .
The WHO update on 28 September 2012 said the virus did not seem to pass easily from person to person.
Amakuru mashya ya WHO yo kuwa 28 Nzeri 2012 avuga ko virusi itapfa kuva byoroshye mu muntu umwe ijya mu wundi.
However, on 12 May 2013, a case of human-to-human transmission in France was confirmed by the French Ministry of Social Affairs and Health.
Nyamara, kuwa 12 Gicurasi 2013, Minisiteri y’imibereho myiza n’ubuzima yo mu gihugu cy’Ubufaransa yemeje ko hari umuntu wandujwe iyi virusi n’undi muntu.
In addition, cases of human-to-human transmission were reported by the Ministry of Health in Tunisia.
byongeye kandi, Minisiteri y’ubuzimo yo muri Tuniziya yatangaje ko hari abantu banduzanyije iyi virusi.
Two confirmed cases involved people who seemed to have caught the disease from their late father, who became ill after a visit to Qatar and Saudi Arabia.
Babiri bagaragayeho ubwo bwandu barimo abandujwe iyi ndwara na papa witabye Imana, warwaye nyuma yo kugirira ingendo mu bihugu bya Qatar na Saudi Arabia.
Despite this, it appears the virus had trouble spreading from human to human, as most individuals who are infected do not transmit the virus.
Nubwo byari bimeze gutya, bigaragara ko iyi virusi igorwa no kuva mu muntu ijya mu wundi, kubera ko abantu benshi bayanduye batayanduza.
The final name for the virus is Middle East respiratory syndrome coronavirus (MERS-CoV).
Izina rya nyuma ry’iyi virusi ni “Middle East respiratory syndrome coronavirus (MERS-CoV)”.

The only U.S. cases (both survived) were recorded in May 2014.In May 2015, an outbreak of MERS-CoV occurred in the Republic of Korea, when a man who had traveled to the Middle East, visited four hospitals in the Seoul area to treat his illness.

Abantu babiri gusa bo muri Leta Zunze Ubumwe z’Amerika (bombi ikaba itarabahitanye) nibo bagaragaye muri Gicurasi 2014. Muri Gicurasi 2015, MERS-CoV, iki cyorezo cyagaragaye mu Repubulika ya Koreya, igihe umugabo wari waragirye ingendo mu bihugu byo mu Burasirazuba bwo hagati, yagiye mu bitaro bine byo mu gace ko muri Seoul kwivuza.
This caused one of the largest outbreaks of MERS-CoV outside the Middle East.
Ibi byatumye MERS-CoV ikwirakwira hanze y’ibihugu byo mu Burasirazuba bwo hagati .
As of December 2019, 2,468 cases of MERS-CoV infection had been confirmed by laboratory tests, 851 of which were fatal, a mortality rate of approximately 34.5%.
Nko mu Kuboza 2019, ibizamini byo muri laboratwari byagaragaje abantu 2.468 banduye MERS-CoV, 851 muri bo bitabye Imana, ijanisha ry’imfu rikaba ribarirwa kuri 34,5%.
In December 2019, a pneumonia outbreak was reported in Wuhan, China.
Mu Kuboza 2019, icyorezo gifata ibice by’ubuhumekero cyagaragaye muri Wuhan, Ubushinwa.

On 31 December 2019, the outbreak was traced to a novel strain of coronavirus, which was given the interim name 2019-nCoV by the World Health Organization (WHO), later renamed SARS-CoV-2 by the International Committee on Taxonomy of Viruses.

Kuwa 31 Kuboza 2019, icyorezo gishya cya koronavirusi , cyahise gihabwa n’Ishami ry’Umuryango w’Abibumbye Ryita ku Buzima(WHO) izina ry’agateganyo rya 2019-nCoV, nyuma cyaje guhabwa izina rya SARS-CoV-2 na Komite mpuzamahanga ikurikirana ibyorezo.

Some researchers have suggested the Huanan Seafood Wholesale Market may not be the original source of viral transmission to humans.As of 17 April 2020, there have been at least 153,822 confirmed deaths and more than 2,240,191 confirmed cases in the coronavirus pneumonia pandemic.

Bamwe mu bashakashatsi batanze igitekerezo ko iyi virusi yandurwa n’abantu itaturutse muri Huanan Seafood Wholesale Market. Kugeza ku wa 17 Mata 2020, nibura abantu 153.822 bari bamaze guhitanwa nayo naho abarenga 2.240.191 bari bamaze kwandura icyorezo cya koronavirusi.
The Wuhan strain has been identified as a new strain of Betacoronavirus from group 2B with approximately 70% genetic similarity to the SARS-CoV.
Icyorezo cya Wuhan cyagaragajwe nk’ubwoko bushya bwa Betacoronavirus yo mu itsindarya 2 gifite imiterere isa n’iya SARS-CoV ku kigereranyo cya 70%.
The virus has a 96% similarity to a bat coronavirus, so it is widely suspected to originate from bats as well.
Iyi virusi ifte ibyo ihuriyeho na koronavirusi yo mu gacurama ku kigero cya 96%, kubera ibyo rero birakekwa cyane ko nayo yaba ituruka ku ducurama.
The pandemic has resulted in travel restrictions and nationwide lockdowns in several countries.
Iki cyorezo cyatumye ibihugu byinshi bifata ikemezo cyo guhagarika ingendo no gufunga ibikorwa byinshi.
Coronaviruses have been recognized as causing pathological conditions in veterinary medicine since the 1930s.
Byamenyekanye ko Koronavirusi itera ibibazo bikomeye mu buvuzi bw’amatungo guhera mu myaka ya za 1930.
Except for avian infectious bronchitis, the major related diseases have mainly an intestinal location.
Usibye buronshite iterwa n’ibiguruka, indwara nyisnhi bifitanye isano ziba ziri mu mara.
Coronaviruses primarily infect the upper respiratory and gastrointestinal tract of mammals and birds.
Koronavirusi zibanza gufata ibice byo heju by’ubuhumekero no mu mara y’inyamabere ndetse n’inyoni.
They also cause a range of diseases in farm animals and domesticated pets, some of which can be serious and are a threat to the farming industry.
Zitera kandi indwara zitandukanye mu matugo arara hanze ndetse n’abana n’abantu, zimwe muri zo zikaba zikaze cyane kandi zikaba ari umbogamizi ku bikorwa by’ubworozi.
In chickens, the infectious bronchitis virus (IBV), a coronavirus, targets not only the respiratory tract but also the urogenital tract.
Mu nkoko, virusi ya buronshite (IBV), koronavirusi, ifata imyanya y’ubuhumekero ndetse n’imyanya myibarukiro.
The virus can spread to different organs throughout the chicken.
Virusi ishobora gukwirakwira no mu bindi bice bigize inkoko.

Economically significant coronaviruses of farm animals include porcine coronavirus (transmissible gastroenteritis coronavirus, TGE) and bovine coronavirus, which both result in diarrhea in young animals.
Koronavirusi zikunze kwibasira amatungo zirimo izo mu ngurube (TGE) no mu nka, zombi zikaba zitera impiswi amatungo akiri mato.

Feline coronavirus: two forms, feline enteric coronavirus is a pathogen of minor clinical significance, but spontaneous mutation of this virus can result in feline infectious peritonitis (FIP), a disease associated with high mortality.

Koronavirusi yo mu nyamaswa zo mu bwoko bw’injangwe: ubwoko bubiri, koronavirusi y’injangwe ni indwara igaragaza ubukana bworoheje, ariko ihindagurika rya buri kanya ryayo rishobora gutera ibibazo byo nda (FIP), indwara itwara ubuzima bw’abantu benshi.

Similarly, there are two types of coronavirus that infect ferrets: Ferret enteric coronavirus causes a gastrointestinal syndrome known as epizootic catarrhal enteritis (ECE), and a more lethal systemic version of the virus (like FIP in cats) known as ferret systemic coronavirus (FSC).

Hari kandi ubundi bwoko bubiri bwa koronavirusi bufata inyamaswa zo mu bwoko bw’amafuku: Koronavirusi yo mu mafuku itera uburwayi mu nyama zo mu nda buzwi ku izina rya epizootic catarrhal enteritis (ECE), na virusi yica (nka FIP yo mu njangwe) izi nka ferret systemic coronavirus (FSC).
There are two types of canine coronavirus (CCoV), one that causes mild gastrointestinal disease and one that has been found to cause respiratory disease.
Hari ubwoko bubiri bwa koronavirusi y’imbwa (CCoV), imwe itera uburwayi bwoheje bwo munda n’indi byagaraye ko ifata imyanya y’ubuhumekero .
Mouse hepatitis virus (MHV) is a coronavirus that causes an epidemic murine illness with high mortality, especially among colonies of laboratory mice.
Virusi y’imbeba (MHV) ni koronavirusi itera indwara ikomaka ku mbeba kandi ihitana abantu benshi cyane cyane ahantu hakunze hari za laboratwari nyinshi zipima imbeba nyinshi.
Sialodacryoadenitis virus (SDAV) is highly infectious coronavirus of laboratory rats, which can be transmitted between individuals by direct contact and indirectly by aerosol.
Sialodacryoadenitis virus (SDAV) ni ubwoko bwa koronavirusi yandura cyane ikaba ituruka ku mbeba zo muri laboratwari ishobora kwandurira mu gukoranaho kw’abantu cyangwa mu buryo buziguye mu mwuka.
Some strains of MHV cause a progressive demyelinating encephalitis in mice which has been used as a murine model for multiple sclerosis.
Zimwe mu ndwara za MHV gutuma udutsi two mu bwonko tw’imbeba yakoreweho igeragezwa duturika , .
Significant research efforts have been focused on elucidating the viral pathogenesis of these animal coronaviruses, especially by virologists interested in veterinary and zoonotic diseases.
Ubushakashatsi bwinshi bwashyize imbara mu gusobanura imiterere y’izo koronavirusi, by’umwihariko abahanga mu bijyanye na virusi bibanze mu bijyanye n’amatungo.
Porcine coronavirus (transmissible gastroenteritis coronavirus of pigs, TGEV).
Koronavirusi y’ingurube (ifata inyama zo munda y’ingurube, TGEV).
Bovine coronavirus (BCV), responsible for severe profuse enteritis in of young calves.
Koronavirusi y’inka (BCV), izahaza cyane imitavu.
Feline coronavirus (FCoV) causes mild enteritis in cats as well as severe Feline infectious peritonitis (other variants of the same virus).
Koronavirusi y’injangwe (FCoV) ituma injangwe ibyimba amara ndetse n’ibindi bibazo bikomeye byo kubyimba amara(ibindi bibazo biterwa n’iyi virusi).
the two types of canine coronavirus (CCoV) (one causing enteritis, the other found in respiratory diseases).
Ubwoko bubiri bwa koronavirusi y’imbwa(CCoV) (bumwe butera kubyimba amara, ubundi bugatera ibibazo byo guhumeka).
Turkey coronavirus (TCV) causes enteritis in turkeys.
Koronavirusi ya dendo (TCV) ituma dendo ibyimba amara.
Ferret enteric coronavirus causes epizootic catarrhal enteritis in ferrets.
Koronavirusi yo mu nyamaswa zo mu bwoko bw’amafuku ituma izo nyamaswa zibyima mu myanya y’ubuhumekero.
Ferret systemic coronavirus causes FIP-like systemic syndrome in ferrets.
Koronavirusi yo mu nyamaswa zo mu bwoko bw’amafuku itera ibibazo bya FIP muri izo nyamaswa.
Rabbit enteric coronavirus causes acute gastrointestinal disease and diarrhea in young European rabbits.
Koronavirusi yo mu nkwavu ifata imyanya yo munda igateran’impiswi ku nkwavu.
Porcine epidemic diarrhea virus (PED or PEDV), has emerged around the world.
Virusi y’ingurube itera impiswi (PED cyangwa PEDV), imaze gusakara ku isi hose.
b'Coronavirus disease 2019 (COVID-19) is an infectious disease caused by severe acute respiratory syndrome coronavirus 2 (SARS-CoV-2).
Icyorezo cya koronavirusi ya 2019 (COVID-19) ni indwara yandura itera virusi ifata mu myanya y’ubuhumekero yo mu bwoko bwa 2 (SARS-CoV-2).
Common symptoms include fever, cough, and shortness of breath.
Ibimenyetso ikunze kugaragaza ni umuriro mwinshi, inkorora, no kubura umwuka.
Other symptoms may include fatigue, muscle pain, diarrhea, sore throat, loss of smell, and abdominal pain.
Ibindi bimenyetso by’iyi ndwara birimo umunaniro, kubabara mu mitsi, impiswi, kubabara mu muhogo, gutakaza ubushobozi bwo guhumurirwa no kunukirwa, no kubabara mu nda.
The time from exposure to onset of symptoms is typically around five days but may range from two to fourteen days.
Umuntu wayanduye agaragaza ibimenyetso mu gihe k’iminsi itanu ariko gishobora kuba hagati y’iminsi ibiri na cumi n’ine.
While the majority of cases result in mild symptoms, some progress to viral pneumonia and multi-organ failure.
Mu gihe abenshi mu banduye iyi virusi bagaragaza ibimenyetso byorohereje, bamwe bagira ibibazo byo guhumeka no kumva ingingo nyinshi z’umubiri zacitse intege.
As of 17 April 2020, more than 2.24 million cases have been reported across 210 countries and territories, resulting in more than 153,000 deaths.
Kugeza ku itariki ya 17 Mata 2020, abantu barenga miliyoni 2,24 bari bamaze kwandura mu bihugu n’uduce 210, bituma abagera kuri 153.000 babura ubuzima.
More than 568,000 people have recovered.The virus is primarily spread between people during close contact, often via small droplets produced by coughing, sneezing, or talking.
Abarenga 568,000 barakize. Iyi virusi yandurira mu kwegerana, akenshi binyuze mu matembabuzi asohoka igihe umuntu akoroye, yitsamuye cyangwa avuga .
While these droplets are produced when breathing out, they usually fall to the ground or onto surfaces rather than being infectious over long distances.
Mu gihe aya matembabuzi asohoka igihe umuntu ahumeka, ubusanzwe ahita agwa hasi cyangwa ku kintu aho kuba yakwanduza umuntu uri mu ntera nini.
People may also become infected by touching a contaminated surface and then touching their eyes, nose, or mouth.
Abantu bashobora kwandura iyi ndwara kandi igihe bakoze ahari iyi virusi hanyuma bakikora mu maso, ku mazuru cyangwa ku munwa .
The virus can survive on surfaces up to 72 hours.
Virusi ishobora kumara hanze amasaha agera kuri 72 ikiri nzima.

It is most contagious during the first three days after the onset of symptoms, although spread may be possible before symptoms appear and in later stages of the disease.The standard method of diagnosis is by real-time reverse transcription polymerase chain reaction (rRT-PCR) from a nasopharyngeal swab.

Iba yandura cyane mu minsi itatu ya mbere nyuma yo kugaragaza ibimenyetso, nubwo ishobora no kwandura mbere yo kugaragaza ibimenyetso no mu gihe ubwandu buba butaragiraubukana.Uburyo bwizewe bwo kuyipima ni ubwo bita “real-time reverse transcription polymerase chain reaction (rRT-PCR)” ikorwa bakoresheje ibizamini byafatiwe mu mazuru.
The use of masks is recommended for those who suspect they have the virus and their caregivers.
NI ngombwa ko umuntu ukekwaho ubwandu n’umwitaho bambara udupfukamunwa.
Recommendations for mask use by the general public vary, with some authorities recommending against their use, some recommending their use, and others requiring their use.
Amabwiriza ajyanye no kwambara agapfukamunwa ku bantu bose agenda atandukana, hari bamwe mu bayobozi bagira abantu inama yo kutatwakambara, abandi bagasaba abantu kukambara.
Currently, there is no vaccine or specific antiviral treatment for COVID-19.
Kugeza ubu, nta rukingo cyangwa umuti wihariye uvura COVID-19 bizwi.
Local transmission of the disease has been recorded in most countries across all six WHO regions.
Hari ubwandu hagati y’abantu bari mu gace kamwe byagaragaye mu turere dutandatu twose twa WHO.
Those infected with the virus may be asymptomatic or develop flu-like symptoms such as fever, cough, fatigue, and shortness of breath.
Abanduye iyi virusi bashobora kutagaragaza ibimenyetso cyangwa bakagaragaza ibimenyetso bisa n’iby’ibicurane birimo nko guhinda umuriro, gukorora, kugira umunaniro, no kubura umwuka.

Emergency symptoms include difficulty breathing, persistent chest pain or pressure, confusion, difficulty waking, and bluish face or lips; immediate medical attention is advised if these symptoms are present.

Ibimenyetso bikomeye birimo kugira ingorane mu guhumeka, kugira ububabare buhoraho cyangwa kuremererwa mu gatuza, kugira ibikezikezi mu maso, kunanirwa kugenda, gutukura mu maso cyangwa iminwa; bikaba ari ngomwa guhita umuntu yihutira kujya kwa muganga igihe aagaragaje ibi bimenyetso.
Less commonly, upper respiratory symptoms such as sneezing, runny nose or sore throat may be seen.
Ntibikunze kunaho ko wagira ibimenyetso birimo kugira ibibazo byo mu myanya y’ubuhumekero nko kwitsamura, gupfunagura cyangwa kubabara mu muhogo.
Gastrointestinal symptoms such as nausea, vomiting and diarrhoea have been observed in varying percentages.
Ibimenyetso byo myanya yo mu rwungano ngogozi nko kugira isesemi, kuruka no guhitwa bikunze kugaragara ku ijanisha riri hejuru.
Some cases in China initially presented only with chest tightness and palpitations.
Abarwayi bo mu Bushinwa baragaje bwa mbere ibimenyetso byo gufungana mu gatuza no gutera cyane k’umutima.
In some, the disease may progress to pneumonia, multi-organ failure, and death.
Kuri bamwe, indwara ishobora kugira ubukana bwinshi bikagera aho umuntu abura umwuka, ingingo nyinshi z’umubiri zigahagarara gukora ndetse hakazamo n’urupfu.
This is called the incubation period.
Ibi nibyo bita igihe cyo kwigaragaza kw’indwara.
The incubation period for COVID-19 is typically five to six days but may range from two to 14 days.
igihe cyo kwigaragaza kw’indwara ya COVID-19 ubusanzwe ni iminsi itandatu ariko ishobora kuba hagati y’ibiri na 14.
97.5% of people who develop symptoms will do so within 11.5 days of infection.Reports indicate that not all who are infected develop symptoms.
97.5% by’abantu bagaragaza ibimenyetso icyo gihe gishobora kuba mu minsi 11,5 umuntu ahuye n’ubwandu. Raporo zivuga ko umuntu wese wandye atari ko agaragaza ibimenyetso.
The role of these asymptomatic carriers in transmission is not yet fully known; however, preliminary evidence suggests that they may contribute to the spread of the disease.
Uruhare rw’abanduye batagaragaza ibimenyetso ntabwo ruramenyekana kugezaubu; nyamara, amakuru ahari y’ibanze ni uko bashobora kwanduza abandi.

The proportion of infected people who do not display symptoms is currently unknown and being studied, with the Korea Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (KCDC) reporting that 20% of all confirmed cases remained asymptomatic during their hospital stay.

Umubare w’abantu batajya bagaragaza ibimenyetso kugeza ubu nturamenyekana ariko urimo kwigwaho, hashingiwe ku makuru atangazwa n’Ikigo cyo muri Koreya gishinzwe gukurikirana no kurwanya indwara (KCDC) avuga ko 20% y’abantu bose banduye barinda basezererwa mu bitaro nta bimenyetso bagaragaje.
China's National Health Commission began including asymptomatic cases in its daily cases on 1 April; of the 166 infections on that day, 130 (78%) were asymptomatic at the time of testing.

Komisiyo y’igihugu y’ubuzima yo mu gihugu cy’Ubushinwa kuwa 1 Mata yatangiye gushyira abo bantu ku mibare y’abanduye itangaza buri munsi; mu bantu 166 batangajwe kuri uwo munsi, 130 (78%) nta bimenyetso bagaragazaga igihe bapimwaga.
Both sputum and saliva can carry large viral loads.
Igikororwa n’amacandwe bishobora gutwara ingano nini ya virusi.
Loud talking releases more droplets than normal talking.
Kuvuga cyane bituma hasohoka amatembabuzi menshi kurusha iyo umuntu avuga gahoro.
A study in Singapore found that an uncovered cough can lead to droplets travelling up to 4.5 meters (15 feet).
Ubushakashatsi bwo muri Singapuru ko gukorora utipfutse ku munwa bishobora gutuma amatembabuzi agenda akagera mu ntera ya metero 4,5 (15 feet).

Though the virus is not generally airborne, the National Academy of Science has suggested that bioaerosol transmission may be possible and air collectors positioned in the hallway outside of people's rooms yielded samples positive for viral RNA.
Nubwo virusi itandurira mu mwuka, Ikigo k’igihugu cy’ubumenyi kivuga ko bishoboka kandi umwuka wasohotse mu byumba by’abantu batandukany wakusanyijwe warapimwe basangamo virusi .
Some medical procedures such as intubation and cardiopulmonary resuscitation (CPR) may cause respiratory secretions to be aerosolised and thus result in airborne spread.
Uburyo bwa kiganga burimo nko gushyira agatiyo mu muhogo no kongera umwuka (CPR) bushobora gutuma hari umwuka usohoka bikaba byatuma umuntu yakwanduzwa nawo.

While there are concerns it may spread via feces, this risk is believed to be low.The virus is most contagious when people are symptomatic; while spread may be possible before symptoms emerge, the risk is low.

mu gihe hari abibaza niba umubyeyi ashobora kwanduza umwana atwite, nta kintu kinini kirabyemeza. Virusi iba ishobora kwandura iyo abantu bagaragaza ibimenyetso byayo; mu gihe hari amahirwe make yo kuba umuntu yakwanduza mbere y’uko ibimenyetso bigaragara,.

The European Centre for Disease Prevention and Control (ECDC) says while it is not entirely clear how easily the disease spreads, one person generally infects two to three others.The virus survives for hours to days on surfaces.

Ikigo gishinzwe kurinda no gukurikirana indwara cyo mu Burayi (ECDC) kivuga ko nubwo uburyo virusi yandura ku buryo bworoshye butaramenyekana, umuntu ashobora kwanduza abantu bari hagati ya babiri na batatu. Viusi imara hanze igihe kibarirw mu masaha kugeza ku minsi.
Specifically, the virus was found to be detectable for one day on cardboard, for up to three days on plastic (polypropylene) and stainless steel (AISI 304), and for up to four hours on 99% copper.

By’umwihariko, virusi yamaze umunsi umwe ku kibaho, iminsi igera kuri itatu kuri pulasitiki (polypropylene) no ku byuma bikomeye(AISI 304), n’amasaha ane ku byuma bigondeka byoroshye ku kigero cya 99%.
This, however, varies depending on the humidity and temperature.
Ibi nyamara bishobora guhinduka bitewe n’ubukonje ndetse n’ubushyuhe.
Soap and detergent are also effective if correctly used; soap products degrade the virus' fatty protective layer, deactivating it, as well as freeing them from skin and other surfaces.

Isabune n’imiti yica udukoko, iyo bikoreshejwe neza, bishobora kwica virusi; isabune yangiza” ikinure kirinda virusi”, ikakibuza gukora ndetse ikanagikura ku mubiri cyangwa ahandu hantu iyo virusi iri.

Other solutions, such as benzalkonium chloride and chlorhexidine gluconate (a surgical disinfectant), are less effective.In a Hong Kong study, saliva samples were taken a median of two days after the start of hospitalization.

Ibindi bikoreshwa birimo imiti yitwa benzalkonium chloride na chlorhexidine gluconate( umuti wica udukoko), ariko nta bushobozi bwinshi ifite. Mu bushakashatsi bwo muri Hong Kong, hafashwe ibizamini by’amacandwe mu gihe k’iminsi ibiri nyuma yo kujyanwa mu bitaro.
In five of six patients, the first sample showed the highest viral load, and the sixth patient showed the highest viral load on the second day tested.
Batanu mu barwayi batandatu, ikizamini cya mbere cyagaragayemo ingano nini ya virusi, hanyuma uwa gatandatu yagaragayemo ingano nini ya virusi mu bipimo byo ku munsi wa kabiri .

Severe acute respiratory syndrome coronavirus 2 (SARS-CoV-2) is a novel severe acute respiratory syndrome coronavirus, first isolated from three people with pneumonia connected to the cluster of acute respiratory illness cases in Wuhan.

Indwara ikomeye y’igikatu ya coronavirus 2 SARS-CoV-2 ni virusi nshya izahaza imyanya yo mu buhumekero, yagaragaye bwa mbere I Wuhan ku bantu batatu bari bafite ibibazo byo guhumeka bifitanye isano n’indwara z’ubuhumekero.
All features of the novel SARS-CoV-2 virus occur in related coronaviruses in nature.
Ibintu byose biranga virusi ya SARS-CoV-2 bigaragara mu bwoko bwa koronavirusi.
Outside the human body, the virus is killed by household soap, which bursts its protective bubble.SARS-CoV-2 is closely related to the original SARS-CoV.
Hanze y’umubiri w’umuntu, virusi yicwa n’isabune ikoreshwa mu rugo, yica ikinure kirinda virusi. SARS-CoV-2 ifitanye isano ya hafi na SARS-CoV ya mbere.

The lungs are the organs most affected by COVID-19 because the virus accesses host cells via the enzyme angiotensin-converting enzyme 2 (ACE2), which is most abundant in the type II alveolar cells of the lungs.
COVID-19 yibasira cyane cyane ibihaha, kubera ko virusi igera inyuze mu cyo bita “enzyme angiotensin-converting enzyme 2 (ACE2)”, igaraga ku bwinshi mu bihaha.
The virus uses a special surface glycoprotein called a "spike" (peplomer) to connect to ACE2 and enter the host cell.
Virusi ikoresha igice cyayo k’inyuma kitwa “spike” (ikinure gikoze nk’ihembe) kikayihuza na ACE2 hanyuma ikinjira mu kinyabuzima.
Acute cardiac injury was found in 12% of infected people admitted in hospital in Wuhan, China, and is more frequent in severe disease.
12% y’abanduye bakajyanwa mu bitaro byo muri Wuhanm, mu gihugu cy’Ubushinwa, basanganywe ibibazo bikomeye by’umutima kandi ibi bikunze kugaragara no mu ndwara zikomeye.

Rates of cardiovascular symptoms is high, owing to the systemic inflammatory response and immune system disorders during disease progression, but acute myocardial injury may also be related to ACE2 receptors in the heart.

Ikigero cy’abantu bagaragaza ibimenyetso by’ibibazo by’umutima kiri hejuru, bitewe no kubyimba no kwangirika kw’uburinzi bw’umubiri bihita bibaho uko indwara igenda igira ubukana, ariko ibibazo byo kwangirika kw’imitsi yo ku mutima bishobora kugirana isano n’umutima w’uwanduye ACE2 receptors.
ACE2 receptors are highly expressed in the heart and are involved in heart function.
Virusi ya ACE2 ihita yirukira mu mutima kandi ikagira uruhare mu mikorere y’umutima.

A high incidence of thrombosis (31%) and venous thromboembolism (25%) have been found in ICU patients with COVID-19 infections and may be related to poor prognosis.Autopsies of people who died of COVID-19 have found diffuse alveolar damage (DAD), and lymphocyte-containing inflammatory infiltrates within the lung.

Abarwayi bo muri ICU banduye COVID-19 bagaragaje ibibazo Kubanagamira itembera ry’amaraso (31%) no kwangiza inzira z’amaraso (25%), bikaba bifitanye isano n’amahirwe make yo gukira. Ibizamini byafashwe ku bantu bishwe na COVID-19 byerekanye kwangirika kw’imyanya y’ubuhumekero (DAD), hamwe n’ibibyimba byo mu bihaha.
Although SARS-COV-2 has a tropism for ACE2-expressing epithelial cells of the respiratory tract, patients with severe COVID-19 have symptoms of systemic hyperinflammation.
Nubwo SARS-COV-2 ishobora kubana ACE2-mu mubiri na iherereye mu turemangingo two mu myanya y’ubuhumekero, abarwayi ba COVID-19 baagaragaza ibimenyetso byo kubyimba gukabije.
In particular, pathogenic GM-CSF-secreting T-cells were shown to correlate with the recruitment of inflammatory IL-6-secreting monocytes and severe lung pathology in COVID-19 patients.
By’umwihariko, uturemangingo twaT dusohorwa n’indwara ya GM-CSF byagaragaye ko dukorana n’uturemangingo IL-6-dutera kubyimba mu barwayi ba COVID-19.
Lymphocytic infiltrates have also been reported at autopsy.
Ipimwa ryagaragaje uturemangingo tw’ubwirinzi mu mubiri w’uwahitanywe n’iyo virusi.
The WHO has published several testing protocols for the disease.
Ishami ry’Umuryango w’Abibumbye ryita ku Buzima WHO ryatangaje uburyo bwinshi bwo gupima icyorezo.
The standard method of testing is real-time reverse transcription polymerase chain reaction (rRT-PCR).
Uburyo bwizewe bwo gupima icyorezo ni ubwitwa “real-time reverse transcription polymerase chain reaction (rRT-PCR)”.
The test is typically done on respiratory samples obtained by a nasopharyngeal swab; however, a nasal swab or sputum sample may also be used.
Ibipimo bikorerwa ku bizamini byafatiwe mu myanya y’ubuhumekero hakoreshejwe amatembabuzi yo mu mazuru; nyamara , ibimwira n’igikororwa nabyo bishobora gukoreshwa .
Results are generally available within a few hours to two days.
Ibisubizo biboneka mu gihe gikera ku masaha make kugeza mu minsi ibiri.
Blood tests can be used, but these require two blood samples taken two weeks apart and the results have little immediate value.
Hashobora gupimwa amaraso, ariko bisaba ibipimo bibiri by’amaraso byafaswhe mu byumweru bibiri bitandukanye kandi ibisubizo biba bifite agaciro gake ako kanya.

Chinese scientists were able to isolate a strain of the coronavirus and publish the genetic sequence so laboratories across the world could independently develop polymerase chain reaction (PCR) tests to detect infection by the virus.

Inzobere zo mu Bushinwa zashoboye gushyira ku ruhande uturemangingo twa koronavirusi hanyuma igatangariza isi yose ibyavuye muri laboratwari kugirango ishobore mu bwisanzure gukora uturemangingo (PCR) twakoreshwa mu gupima ubwandu bwa virusi.
As of 4 April 2020, antibody tests (which may detect active infections and whether a person had been infected in the past) were in development, but not yet widely used.

Kugeza kuwa 4 Mata 2020,hari ibipimo byarimo gukorwa ku basirikari barinda umubiri ( bishobora kwerekana ubwandu bukiri mu mubiri cyangwa niba umuntu yabayarahuye n’ubwandu mu gihe cyashize) ,ariko ntibyari byagatingiye gukoreshw ahantu henshi.
The Chinese experience with testing has shown the accuracy is only 60 to 70%.
Ubunararibonye bw’abashinwa mu gupima bwagaragaje ubushobozi bwo ku kigero cya 60% kugeza kuri 70%.

The FDA in the United States approved the first point-of-care test on 21 March 2020 for use at the end of that month.Diagnostic guidelines released by Zhongnan Hospital of Wuhan University suggested methods for detecting infections based upon clinical features and epidemiological risk.

Ikigo gishinzwe ubuziranenge bw’ibiribwa n’imiti (FDA) cyo muri Leta Zunze z’Amerika cyemeje ahantu ho gupimira kuwa 21 Werurwe 2020 hagomba gutangira gukoreshwa mu mpera z’ukwezi. Amabwiriza ajyanye no gupima yatangajwe n’Ibitaro bya Zhongnan bya kaminuza ya Wuhan byagaragaje uburyo bwo gupima ubwandu hashingiwe kubigaragazwa no kwa muganga mdetse n’ibijyanye n’ingaruka z’icyorezo .
Bilateral multilobar ground-glass opacities with a peripheral, asymmetric and posterior distribution are common in early infection.
Mu ntangiriro ubwandu bukunze kurangwa no kwihisha k’uturemangingo twa virusi, tukirunda hamwe, tukitandukanya n’umubiri twinjiyemo nyuma tukazakwirakwira hose.
Subpleural dominance, crazy paving (lobular septal thickening with variable alveolar filling), and consolidation may appear as the disease progresses.
Uko icyorezo kigenda gikura, kigenda gikwira mu myanya y’ubuhumekero, kigakora inzira (kubyimbisha imyanya y’ubuhumekero gikoresheje gufunga inzira z’umwuka) no kwibumbira hamwe.
Few data are available about microscopic lesions and the pathophysiology of COVID-19.
Hari amakuru make ajyanye n’ifoto yo muri mikorosikopi ndetse n’imiterere bya COVID-19.
The main pathological findings at autopsy are:
Iby’ingezi bushakashatsi ku miterere ya virusi bwakorewe ku murambo ni :
Macroscopy: pleurisy, pericarditis, lung consolidation and pulmonary oedema
Ibigaragarira amaso: ibibyimba mu myanya y’ubuhumekero, kubyimba kw’ibice bikikije umutima,gufungana kw’inzira z’ubuhumekero
Four types of severity of viral pneumonia can be observed:
hagaragaye ubwoko butatu bw’ibibazo bikomeye by’ubumekero biterwa na virusi:
mild pneumonia: pulmonary oedema, pneumocyte hyperplasia, large atypical pneumocytes, interstitial inflammation with lymphocytic infiltration and multinucleated giant cell formation

Kubura umwuka byoroheje: utubyimba turimo amazi mu bihaha, kwiyongera k’’uturemangingo two mu myanya y’ubuhumekero, ibibyimba bidasanzwe mu buhumekero, guturika k’utubyimba no kwirema k’uturemangingo dutandukanye
severe pneumonia: diffuse alveolar damage (DAD) with diffuse alveolar exudates.
umusonga ukaze: ukwirakwiza ukwangirika kw’inzira zinyuramo umwuka (DAD) maze amashyira agakwirakwira.
DAD is the cause of acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS) and severe hypoxemia.
DAD niyo nyirabayazana y’indwara zikomeye zifata imyanya y’ubuhumekero (ARDS) no gufungana kw’inzira z’amaraso.
healing pneumonia: organisation of exudates in alveolar cavities and pulmonary interstitial fibrosis
Indwara zo mu buhumekero zitangiye koroha: kwirunda hamwe kw’amashyira mu myanya y’ubuhumekero no mu bihaha
Blood: disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC); leukoerythroblastic reaction
Amaraso: kuvira imbere (DIC); kwirema k’uturemangingo dushya mu maraso

Preventive measures to reduce the chances of infection include staying at home, avoiding crowded places, washing hands with soap and water often and for at least 20 seconds, practising good respiratory hygiene and avoiding touching the eyes, nose or mouth with unwashed hands.

Mu ngamba zo kugabanya ikwirakwira ry’ubwandu harimo kuguma mu rugo, kwirinda kujya ahantu hateraniye abantu benshi, gukaraba kenshi intoki ukoresheje isabune n’amazi kandi bigakorwa nibura mu gihe cy’amasegonda 20, kugirira isuku imyanya y’ubuhumekero no kwirinda kwikora ku maso, amazuru cyangwa ku munwa utakarabye intoki.
The CDC recommends covering the mouth and nose with a tissue when coughing or sneezing and recommends using the inside of the elbow if no tissue is available.

CDC igira abantu inama yo kwipfuka umunwa ukoresheje agatambaro gasukuye mu gihe ukoroye cyangwa witsamuye cyangwa ugashyira ku munwa igice cy’akaboko kiri imbere y’inkokora igihe nta gatambaro gahari .
Proper hand hygiene after any cough or sneeze is encouraged.
Ni ngombwa gukaraba intoki igihe cyose umaze gukorora cyangwa kwitsamura.

The CDC has recommended the use of cloth face coverings in public settings, in part to limit transmission by asymptomatic individuals.Social distancing strategies aim to reduce contact of infected persons with large groups by closing schools and workplaces, restricting travel and cancelling large public gatherings.

CDC ikangurira abantu kwambara agapfukamunwa igihe bavuye mu rugo, mu rwego rwo gukumira ikwirakwira ry’ubwandu rikozwe n’abantu batajya bagaragaza ibimenyetso. Uburyo bwo guhana intera bugamije kugabanya iyegerana ry’abantu bazima n’abafite ubwandu hafungwa amashuri, aho abantu bakorera akazi, guhagarika ingendo no kubuza abantu guteranira ahantu hamwe .
Distancing guidelines also include that people stay at least 6 feet (1.8 m) apart.
Amabwiriza avuga ko abantu bagomba guhana intera ya 6 feet ingana na metero 1,8.

There is no medication known to be effective at preventing COVID-19.As a vaccine is not expected until 2021 at the earliest, a key part of managing COVID-19 is trying to decrease the epidemic peak, known as "flattening the curve".

Nta muti uzwi uvura COVID-19. Kubera ko urukingo biteganyijwe ko hafi rwaboneka ari muri 2021uburyo bwiza kwo guhangana n’iki cyorezo ni ugushyiraho ingamaba zituma ubwandu bushya bwa COVID-19 bugabanuka buzwi ku izina rya "flattening the curve" mu rurimi rw’Icyongereza.
